{{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Alfie Hale | image = | fullname = Alfred Hale | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1939|8|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Waterford]], Republic of Ireland | position = [[Inside forward]] | youthyears1= 195x–1957 | youthclubs1= St. Joseph's Juniors | years1 = 1956–1957 | years2 = 1957–1958 | years3 = 1958–1960 | years4 = 1960–1962 | years5 = 1962–1965 | years6 = 1965–1966 | years7 = 1966–1974 | years8 = 1974–1975 | years9 = 1975–1976 | years10 = 1976–1977 | years11 =1981–1982 | years12 =1982–1983 | clubs1 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford]] | clubs2 = [[Cork Hibernians F.C.|Cork Hibernians]] | clubs3 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford]] | clubs4 = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] | clubs5 = [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] | clubs6 = [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] | clubs7 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford]] | clubs8 = [[Cork Celtic F.C.|Cork Celtic]] | clubs9 = [[St Patrick's Athletic F.C.|St Patrick's Athletic]] | clubs10 = [[Limerick F.C.|Limerick]] | clubs11 = [[Thurles Town F.C.|Thurles Town]] | clubs12 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford]] | caps1 = 5 | goals1 = 5 | caps2 = ? | goals2 = 1 | caps3 = 34 | goals3 = 21 | caps4 = 5 | goals4 = 1 | caps5 = 119 | goals5 = 42 | caps6 = 34 | goals6 = 21 | caps7 = 165 | goals7 = 111 | caps8 = ? | goals8 = 9 | caps9 = ? | goals9 = 3 | caps10 = 7 | goals10 = 2 | caps11 = 22 | goals11 = 1 | caps12 = 8 | goals12 = 0 | nationalyears1= 1962–1973 | nationalteam1= [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] | nationalcaps1= 14 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | manageryears1 = 1969–1970 | manageryears2 = 1974–1975 | manageryears3 = 1981–1982 | manageryears4 = 1982–1988 | manageryears5 = 1988–1989 | manageryears6 = 1991–1993 | manageryears7 =1995–1999 | managerclubs1 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]] | managerclubs2 = [[Cork Celtic F.C.|Cork Celtic]] | managerclubs3 = [[Thurles Town F.C.|Thurles Town]] | managerclubs4 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]] | managerclubs5 = [[Cobh Ramblers F.C.|Cobh Ramblers]] | managerclubs6 = [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]] | managerclubs7 =[[Kilkenny City A.F.C.|Kilkenny City]] }} '''Alfred "Alfie" Hale''' (born 28 August 1939 in [[Waterford]], Republic of Ireland) is a former Irish [[association football|footballer]] and manager who played for several clubs in both the [[League of Ireland]] and the [[Football League|English League]], most notably, [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]], [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] and [[Cork Celtic F.C.|Cork Celtic]]. During his career Hale scored 153 goals in the League of Ireland and a further 66 with English League clubs. As an international, Hale also played for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]].
After retiring as a player Hale managed several teams in the League of Ireland, most notably, [[Cork Celtic F.C.|Cork Celtic]], [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]] and [[Kilkenny City F.C.|Kilkenny City]]. In June 2003, Hale and such other notable [[Waterford]] footballers as [[Davy Walsh]], [[Paddy Coad]], [[Peter Thomas (footballer born 1944)|Peter Thomas]], [[Jim Beglin]] and [[John O'Shea]] were honoured by the Waterford City Council and presented with a [[Waterford Crystal]] vase.
==Playing career==
===Waterford=== Hale spent much of his playing and coaching career at [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]]. His father, three brothers and two uncles had all played for the club in the 1930s. In 1930 the trio even formed an all-Hale half-back line in a league game at home to [[Bohemians F.C.|Bohemians]]. At the age of 17 Hale junior along with [[Peter Fitzgerald (footballer)]] made a scoring [[League of Ireland]] debut at Kilcohan Park on [[St Patrick's Day]] 1957 in a 3–1 win over Bohemians<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/1957/0318/Pg004.html#Ar00412:2C67E82EA7FD31969435F6AA2D57B131B7C62F27E83027FD3037E83397FD2FD85834186D]</ref>
He left Waterford in 1960 but after seven seasons in the [[Football League|English League]], he returned in 1966. Then together with [[Johnny Matthews]], he became a central figure in a Waterford team that dominated the [[League of Ireland]]. In 1971–72 Hale was player-manager of the side when they beat [[Cork Hibernians F.C.|Cork Hibernians]] in dramatic circumstances at [[Flower Lodge]] to claim his fifth league title in six seasons. In both 1971–72 and 1972–73 he also finished as joint top goalscorer in the league, scoring 22 and 20 goals respectively.<ref name=rsssf/> He is also the 7th highest [[League of Ireland]] goalscorer of all time with 153 league goals.<ref name=rsssf>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iertops.html Top goalscorers in League of Ireland – RSSSF] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406093820/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iertops.html |date=6 April 2012 }}</ref> He was awarded a benefit game in August 1971.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/1971/0805/Pg004.html www.irishtimes.com (subscription required)]</ref>
He scored twice against [[AC Omonia]] in the [[1972–73 European Cup]].
===Aston Villa=== In June 1960, aged 19, Hale was sold by [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]] to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] for a fee of £4,500. However, Hale failed to establish himself in the Villa first team and went on to make just 7 first team appearances, scoring 2 goals. Despite this Hale won his first international cap for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] while at Villa.<ref>[http://www.avfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/OnThisDay/0,,10265~855241,00.html Aston Villa site] {{Dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref>
===Doncaster Rovers=== Hale signed for [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in the summer of 1962 and made his debut for the club on 18 August in a 2–0 defeat to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in the [[Football League Fourth Division]]. He scored four goals in a single game as he helped Rovers to a record league win when they beat [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]]. In three seasons with Rovers, Hale made 119 league appearances and scored 42 goals. He also made 7 appearances for Rovers in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] and 9 in the [[FA Cup]], scoring 2 further goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doncasterrovers.co.uk/players/GtoJ/Hale,Alfie.htm|title=Alfie Hale: inside forward 1962–1965|publisher=Doncasterrovers.co.uk|accessdate=9 April 2012}}</ref>
===Republic of Ireland international=== Between 1962 and 1973, Hale made 14 appearances and scored 2 goals for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team]]. He made his senior international debut on 8 April 1962 in a 3–2 home defeat against [[Austria national football team|Austria]]. Hale went on to score twice for the Republic of Ireland, both goals coming in 1968, against [[Poland national football team|Poland]] and then Austria. He made his last appearance for the Republic of Ireland on 21 October 1973 as a substitute in a 1–0 home win against Poland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerscene.ie/sssenior/player.php?id=328|title=Alfie Hale|work=International Mens Statistics|publisher=Soccerscene.ie|accessdate=9 April 2012}}</ref>
==Coaching career== As a manager Hale would return to [[Waterford United F.C.|Waterford United]] for two further spells. During the first of these, between 1982 until 1986, he guided the club to victory in the [[League of Ireland Cup]] in 1985 and to the [[FAI Cup]] final in 1986. He returned to manage the club again between 1991 and 1993 and helped them achieve promotion from the [[League of Ireland First Division|First Division]] in 1992. In 2005, he briefly returned to Waterford United once again, this time acting as special advisor.
Aside from Waterford, Hale has also coached several other teams in the League of Ireland. He was appointed player/manager of [[Thurles Town F.C.|Thurles Town]] in May 1981<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/1981/0521/Pg003.html#Ar00313:07870E0A972F08776D0A578011F80113A81406276D081780 Irish Times (subscription required)]</ref> where he made history by becoming the League of Ireland's oldest ever goalscorer, and also the only player to score in four different League of Ireland decades. As manager of [[Cobh Ramblers F.C.|Cobh Ramblers]], Hale gave [[Roy Keane]] his debut in 1990. Between 1995 and 1999 he was manager of [[Kilkenny City A.F.C.|Kilkenny City]] and in 1997, with a team which included the likes of his son Richie, Brendan Rea, Paul Cashin and Pascal Keane, he guided them to the First Division title. After leaving Kilkenny, Hale remained active in junior football working with Waterford Crystal F.C. and Tramore F.C, winning the first league in 50 years with Tramore in 2000–01.
==Businessman== At the same time as managing various [[League of Ireland]] clubs, Hale also established himself as a prominent businessman in the [[Waterford]] area. In 1978, he opened a sports shop, currently trading under the name ''Alfie Hale's [[Intersport]]'' and located at Arundal Square.<ref>[http://www.alfiehale.com/about.htm Alfie Hale's Intersport] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707110225/http://www.alfiehale.com/about.htm |date= 7 July 2011 }}</ref> He also owns a chain of pubs including ''Alfie Hale's Bar'' in Ballybricken<ref>[http://ratemypub.ie/pub.php?pubid=4931 Alfie Hale's Bar]</ref> and ''Alfie Hale's Sports Bar'' on Lombard Street.<ref>[http://ratemypub.ie/editpub.php?pubid=4352 Alfie Hale's Sports Bar]</ref>
In December 2008, he settled with the [[Revenue Commissioners]] for over €100,000.<ref>http://www.independent.ie/national-news/former-ireland-player-to-pay-revenue-over-8364100000-1561089.html</ref>
At the end of the [[2012 League of Ireland]] season Hale is tenth in the all-time League of Ireland goalscoring list with 153 league goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iertops.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=5 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406093820/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iertops.html |archivedate=6 April 2012 }}</ref>
==Honours==
===Player=== '''[[Waterford F.C.|Waterford]]'''

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Atul Shah | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1961}} | birth_place = [[Nakuru]], [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | nationality = Kenyan | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Businessman]] & [[Entrepreneur]] | years_active = 1978 — present | organization = Nakumatt Holdings Limited | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | television = | title = [[Managing Director]] & [[CEO]]
'''[[Nakumatt|Nakumatt Holdings Limited]]''' | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | module = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Atul Shah''' is a [[businessman]] and [[entrepreneur]] in [[Kenya]]. He is the [[Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the Nakumatt Holdings Limited, the parent company of [[Nakumatt|Nakumatt Supermarkets]], the largest, privately owned supermarket chain in the [[African Great Lakes]] area, with branches in [[Kenya]], [[Uganda]], [[Tanzania]] and [[Rwanda]]. {{asof|September 2014}}, the retail chain maintained 50 stores in four countries, employed over 7,000 people and had annual sales in excess of US$650 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/no-secret-to-doing-business-in-africa-says-nakumatt-md-atul-shah/43244/| title=‘No Secret To Doing Business In Africa,’ Says Nakumatt Managing Director, Atul Shah|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=2 December 2014|first=Dinfin|last=Mulupi|publisher=How We Made It In Africa}} ==Background and education== He was born in [[Nandi Hills, Kenya|Nandi Hills]], Kenya in 1961. In 1965, when Atul was four years old, the family relocated to [[Nakuru]]. Atul's father, '''Mangalal Shah''', who had migrated to Kenya from India in 1947, opened a retail clothing store opposite the Nakuru open air market. Atul' s older brother, Vimal started working in the business in 1970. In 1975 Mangalal began exporting clothing to Uganda, often on credit. Towards the end of 1976, with debtors behind on their payments and creditors demanding for their money, Atul's father declared bankruptcy, with total debts of KSh1.2 million. The store was closed and Mangalal went to work for his brother '''Hasmukh Shah''', who then owned a shop called '''Nakuru Mattresses'''. Following the closure of their father's business, Atul Shah and his brother, Vimal Shah opened a clothing store that they named '''Furmatts''', which among other things, sold bed sheets which the brothers stitched at home. In 1978, due to booming business, supported by the 1970s coffee boom in East Africa, the two sons and their father managed to pay off the KSh1.2 million debt. They bought Nakuru Mattress from their uncle, who relocated to the United Kingdom.{{cite web|accessdate=2 December 2014| url=http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/article/2000036154/the-non-quitter-who-founded-nakumatt-supermarkets?articleID=2000036154&story_title=the-non-quitter-who-founded-nakumatt-supermarkets&pageNo=1|date=31 May 2011|first=Kenneth| last=Kwama|title=The Non-Quitter Who Founded Nakumatt Supermarkets| newspaper=[[The Standard (Kenya)]]}} ==Nakumatt supermarkets== Under new ownership, Nakuru Mattress and Furmatts began integrating their operations. From two stores Nakuru town in 1978, they diversified the list of items on offer. In addition to clothes and mattresses, they began selling saucepans, cooking pots, plastic basins and umbrellas, among other products. In 1984, they opened a store in [[Eldoret]], their first outside of Nakuru. In 1986 the retail chain expanded to [[Nairobi]], with a store on Ukwala Road. Over the next 30 years, the supermarket chain has grown into the largest retailer in Kenya, with over 36 stores, employing over 4,500 people.{{cite web|first=David|last=Herbling|date=23 September 2014|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Nakumatt-s-4-500-employees-win-12pc-salary-raise-/-/539550/2463136/-/cqh71sz/-/index.html|title=Nakumatt’s 4,500 Employees Win 12 Percent Salary Raise|newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] (Nairobi)|accessdate=2 December 2014}} In 2008, the retailer opened its first outlet outside of Kenya, in [[Kigali]], [[Rwanda]]. New branches in neighboring [[Uganda]] followed in 2009. The first store in [[Tanzania]] came in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesstimes.co.tz/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1605:nakumatt-enters-tanzania-market&catid=40:marketandeconomy&Itemid=58|title=Nakumatt Enters Tanzania Market|last=Times Reporter|first=.|date=16 December 2011| accessdate=2 December 2014|newspaper=[[Business Times (Tanzania)|Tanzania Business Times]] (Dar es Salaam)}} The retail chain has plans to expand operations to [[Burundi]] and [[South Sudan]] in the next two to three years.{{cite web|title=Nakumatt: From Mattress Shop To African Chain|date=19 April 2012|accessdate=2 December 2014|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/19/us-africainvest-summit-nakumatt-idUSBRE83I12V20120419|publisher=[[Reuters]]|last=Miriri|first=Duncan}} ==Wealth== In 2013, Atul Shah is reported to have valued shareholders' equity in the retail chain at US$400 million (KSh34 billion at that time).{{cite web|accessdate=2 December 2014|last=Mwaniki| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Nakumatt-valued-at-Sh34bn-says-MD--/-/539552/2055344/-/11a2x3v/-/index.html|first=Charles| date=31 October 2013|title=Nakumatt Valued At KSh34 Billion, Says Managing Director|newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] (Nairobi)}} The privately owned family business does not publish its financial statements. However, given that the family is the majority shareholder, Atul Shah is one of Kenya's wealthiest individuals. ==Personal life== Atul Shah is married with two children.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} ==See also== * [[List of wealthiest people in Kenya]] * [[List of supermarket chains in Kenya]] * [[Economy of Kenya]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nakumatt.net/ Nakumatt Holdings Official Website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Shah, Atul}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kenyan people of Indian descent]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kenyan people of Gujarati descent]]

revision.text:
'''Carl-Peter Edmund Moriz Forster'''<ref>{{cite web|author=Stocks |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=788104&ticker=GM |title=Stocks - Bloomberg |publisher=Investing.businessweek.com |date=2017-12-11 |accessdate=2018-02-22}}</ref> (born 9 May 1954, in [[London]]), is an [[England|English]] born [[Germany|German]] [[businessman]]. Forster was the group [[Chief Executive]] of [[Tata Motors]] between January, 2010<ref name="tatamotors.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.tatamotors.com/our_world/press_releases.php?ID%3D516%26action%3DPull |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206041016/http://www.tatamotors.com/our_world/press_releases.php?ID=516&action=Pull |archivedate=2010-12-06 |df= }}</ref> and 9 September 2011.<ref name="BBConC-PFResignation">{{cite web|author=Jorn Madslien |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14859137 |title=Tata Motors chief Carl-Peter Forster resigns - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-02-22}}</ref>
==Biography== Born in London, Forster was raised in London, [[Bonn]] and [[Athens]]. His father was a German [[diplomat]]. Forster holds degrees in Economics from [[Bonn University]], and in Aviation and Space Technology from [[Munich University of Technology]].
===Career=== On graduation in 1982, Forster joined [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey]] as a consultant in [[Munich]].
===BMW=== In 1986, he joined [[BMW]] where he held various leadership positions before becoming Managing Director of BMW [[South Africa]] in 1996, and the board member responsible for all vehicle development projects in 1999.
===General Motors=== In April 2001, Forster was appointed Chairman and Managing Director of [[Adam Opel AG]]. In June 2004 he became President of GM Europe, based in [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]], and Chairman of the Opel Supervisory Board. In April 2005 he also became Chairman of [[Saab Automobile|Saab]]. On 1 January 2006, he was additionally appointed [[General Motors]] Group Vice President and a member of the GM Automotive Strategy Board, and took over the role as the senior-ranking executive for [[General Motors|GM]]’s activities in Europe.<ref name=WSJ1>[https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091106-713409.html GM: Forster To Leave Co; External Search For New Europe CEO]</ref>
On November 3, 2009 General Motors announced that it would retain ownership of its [[Opel]] subsidiary .<ref name=WSJ2>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125728725957326159?mod=WSJ_hpp_LEFTTopStories GM Throws Opel Deal Into Reverse ]</ref> Forster commented about GM’s decision not to sell the units to [[Magna International]]:<ref name=times>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/engineering/article6906710.ece GM Europe president quits following Opel U-Turn]</ref> {{cquote|Such a sudden shift isn’t comprehensible. I hoped that it would have come to a much different outcome}} On 6 November 2009 General Motors confirmed that Forster would be leaving all positions with GM Group globally.<ref name=WSJ1 />
===Tata Motors=== On 15 February 2010 India's [[Tata Motors]] announced that Carl Peter Forster has been appointed as the group CEO with overall responsibility for Tata Motors globally, including that of its British unit [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]] and [[Land Rover]].<ref name="tatamotors.com"/>
Following a surprise announcement on Friday 9 September 2011 it was revealed that Carl-Peter would step down from his group CEO role due to 'unavoidable personal circumstances'. However, he remained on the Tata Motors board of directors in a non-Executive capacity.
===Gordon Murray Design Limited=== Ex-Tata group CEO joined Gordon Murray design house.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmurraydesign.com/press.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002054535/http://www.gordonmurraydesign.com/press.php |archivedate=2013-10-02 |df= }} Undated press release accessed 27 September 2013</ref>
===Rexam=== In June 2014 it was announced that Forster had been appointed a non-executive director of the UK packaging conglomerate [[Rexam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talent4boards.com/rexam/ |title=Rexam announces Carl-Peter Forster to its Board as Non-Executive Director|date=6 June 2014|publisher=Talent for boards|accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Forster is married and has three children and lives in Oxford.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819120354/http://www.forbes.com/finance/mktguideapps/personinfo/FromPersonIdPersonTearsheet.jhtml?passedPersonId=926231 |date=August 19, 2007 |title=Profile on Forbes.com }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Forster, Carl Peter}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:General Motors former executives]] [[Category:Chief executives in the automobile industry]] [[Category:Tata Motors]] [[Category:Opel people]]

{{Infobox person | name = Carlos Tavares | image = Carlos Tavares 4 Genf 2018.jpg | image_size = | caption = Carlos Tavares at [[Geneva Motor Show]] 2018 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|08|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = [[Portugal|Portuguese]] | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[École Centrale Paris]] | employer = | occupation = CEO of [[Groupe PSA]] | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = 3 | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }} '''Carlos Tavares''' (born on August 14 1958) is a Portuguese businessman who serves as the [[chief executive officer]] and Chairman of the Managing Board of [[Groupe PSA]], France's largest car manufacturer. He was formerly the [[chief operating officer]] at [[Renault]]<ref name="ftmichael">Michael Stothard, [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5d6230c0-c1ed-11e4-abb3-00144feab7de.html#axzz3XHRelzpJ Classic rally car driving with the FT: Carlos Tavares], ''Financial Times'', March 6, 2015</ref>
==Early life== Carlos Tavares was born in 1958 in [[Portugal]].<ref name="wsjmike">Mike Ramsey, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324677204578187420765528696 Renault's Carlos Tavares: Meet the Next Auto Boss], ''The Wall Street Journal'', December 20, 2012</ref> He grew up in [[Lisbon]].<ref name="wsjmike"/> He graduated from the [[École Centrale Paris]].<ref name="psapeugeot">{{Cite web |url=http://www.psa-peugeot-citroen.com/en/automotive-group/governance/executive-committee/carlos-tavares# |title=PSA Peugeot: Executive Committee |access-date=2015-04-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417032024/http://www.psa-peugeot-citroen.com/en/automotive-group/governance/executive-committee/carlos-tavares# |archive-date=2015-04-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Career== ===Renault=== Tavares started his career at [[Renault]] in 1981.<ref name="wsjmike"/> He was director of the [[Renault Mégane]] II project.<ref name="wsjmike"/>
He then worked for the [[Nissan]] subsidiary of Renault.<ref name="wsjmike"/> By 2009, he oversaw Nissan's presence in North and South America.<ref name="wsjmike"/>
By 2011, he was [[chief operating officer]] for Renault, the number two executive under [[Carlos Ghosn]], the [[chairman]] and [[chief executive officer]] of Renault and Nissan.<ref name="ftpeugeottaps">Michael Stothard, Henry Foy, [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/19894866-55c9-11e3-b6e7-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3XHRelzpJ Peugeot taps former Renault executive Carlos Tavares as chief], ''Financial Times'', November 25, 2013</ref> Tavares had much in common with Ghosn, as both were "raised in Portuguese-speaking environments. Both went on to graduate from French Grandes Ecoles and - perhaps less surprisingly - both like fast cars". However, Tavares resigned from Renault on August 29, 2013, two weeks after publicly saying that he wanted to become CEO at an automaker, and Tavares reportedly refusing Ghosn's demand that he apologize to staff for the gaffe. It was said that Tavares was ambitious and sought more responsibilities at Renault, however Ghosn was only four years older and had no plans to step aside soon.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-peugeot-ceo-carlos-carlos/carlos-vs-carlos-peugeot-move-turns-double-act-to-rivalry-idUSBREA221WL20140303]</ref>
===Groupe PSA=== Tavares has served as the chief executive officer and Chairman of the Managing Board of Groupe PSA since 2014, replacing [[Philippe Varin]].<ref name="ftpeugeottaps"/> During his tenure, he has spearheaded cost-cutting measures and increased the company's market share in China, which returned Groupe PSA back to profitability after several years of losses.<ref name="ftmichael"/><ref>[http://www.autonews.com/article/20161024/OEM02/310249969/carlos-tavares-next-frontier]</ref>
==Personal life== Tavares has three children.<ref>Anne-Sophie Lechevallier, 'Carlos Tavares - L'homme providentiel de PSA', in ''[[Paris Match]]'', 28 November 2013, p. 44</ref> He has been an amateur race car driver since the age of twenty-two.<ref name="wsjmike"/> He has competed in the [[Rallye Monte-Carlo Historique]].<ref name="ftmichael"/> He also collects "classic cars" and owns a "1979 Peugeot 504 V6 Coupé, a 1976 Alpine A110 and a Porsche 912 from 1966".<ref name="ftmichael"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tavares, Carlos}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:École Centrale Paris alumni]] [[Category:Portuguese businesspeople]] [[Category:Renault people]] [[Category:PSA Group]]

revision.text:
'''Common Impact''' is an American [[nonprofit organization]] headquartered in Boston, [[Massachusetts]]. It catalyzes a new, connected economy by aligning business and social purpose, connecting [[business]] professionals to local nonprofits that need assistance in [[information technology]], [[marketing]], [[human resources]], operations and finance. Common Impact's model for [[social change]] involves [[social innovation]], [[employee engagement]], and [[corporate social responsibility]].
==History==
Theresa M. Ellis co-founded Common Impact in 2000 with Zach Goldstein, both graduates of [[Dartmouth College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alumni.dartmouth.edu/default.aspx?id=495|title=Young Alumni of Dartmouth|accessdate=2008-07-25|publisher=Dartmouth College|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071220234714/http://alumni.dartmouth.edu/default.aspx?id=495|archivedate=2007-12-20|df=}} </ref> Ellis helped connect her friend, an IT professional, to a [[Washington, D.C.]] nonprofit needing assistance with a [[database]] while she was working for another nonprofit. She founded Common Impact to help more [[corporate]] professionals [[Volunteering|volunteer]] their professional [[skills]] and help solve [[social problems]] in the areas of [[health]], [[House|housing]] and [[education]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://alumni.dartmouth.edu/default.aspx?id=879 |title=Celebrating 35 Years of Women at Dartmouth| accessdate=2008-07-25 |publisher=Dartmouth College}}</ref>
==Projects== Many of the projects between corporate employees and nonprofit organizations involve improving databases, creating new marketing materials and restructuring human resources tools. Before each project, Common Impact screens the nonprofit and matches it to a trained team of business professionals who are skilled in the project area. A few examples of projects include redesigning a website<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2008/04/12/more_than_a_helping_hand_for_charities/?page=1.com= |title=More than a helping hand for charities |accessdate=2008-07-15 |publisher=The Boston Globe| first=Sacha | last=Pfeiffer | date=2008-04-12}}</ref> and evaluating marketing materials.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ca.com/us/about/content.aspx?cid=145489 |title=CA Together in the Spotlight |accessdate=2008-07-22 |publisher=CA Together in the Spotlight}}</ref>
==Impact==
Common Impact "helps nonprofits evaluate their internal operations. Then it finds corporate volunteers who can work with them to improve their technology, marketing, and human resource functions." <ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2008/04/12/more_than_a_helping_hand_for_charities/?page=1.com= |title=More than a helping hand for charities |accessdate=2008-07-15 |publisher=The Boston Globe| first=Sacha | last=Pfeiffer | date=2008-04-12}}</ref> These projects have generated over $6 million in resources for the [[nonprofit sector]]. Businesses are increasingly recognizing the importance of [[volunteering]] professional skills as more employees want to help their communities <ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120940853880850351 |title=The Latest Office Perk: Getting Paid to Volunteer |accessdate=2008-07-25 |publisher=The Wall Street Journal| first=Sarah E. | last=Needleman | date=2008-04-29}}</ref> More than 400 corporate employees from companies such as Cisco, Genworth Financial, Fidelity Investments and State Street Corporation have volunteered their skills by working with Common Impact. Some examples of projects Fidelity Investments volunteers worked on are fundraising, case management, databases, and website design.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bcccc.net/index.cfm/fuseaction/Page.viewPage/pageId/1620 |title=In Good Company: Fidelity |publisher=Boston College Center for Corporate Citizenship}}</ref> The organization has connected business professionals to over 150 [[nonprofit organizations]] in [[Greater Boston]], [[New York City]], and [[Richmond, Virginia]]. The [[employee engagement]] relationships Common Impact fosters have translated into an estimated 9,000 hours of skilled volunteer time donated to nonprofit organizations.
==References==
<references/>
==External links== * [http://www.commonimpact.org Common Impact]
==See also==
*[[Venture philanthropy]] *[[Capacity building]]
[[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Boston]] [[Category:Social change]] [[Category:Entrepreneurship organizations]]

'''Riverside''', is a neighborhood that entirely comprises '''Downtown Spokane''' ([[Spokane|the city]]'s central business district), as well as the area immediately to the north of [[Riverfront Park (Spokane)|Riverfront Park]]. Riverside's rough boundaries are [[Interstate 90 (Washington)|I-90]] to the south, Division Street to the east, Maple Street to the west, and across the [[Spokane River]] north to Boone Avenue. Bridges (some of them pedestrian-only) span the river at nearly every block.
==Buildings==
[[File:Holley-Mason Building NRHP 83004262 Spokane County, WA.jpg|thumb|right|Holley-Mason Building]] The Bank of America Financial Center, standing at {{convert|288|ft|m|0}} tall, is the tallest building in Spokane. It was completed in 1981. The nearby Wells Fargo Center is the second tallest building (243 ft), and was completed in one year later 1982. Until 2006, with the construction of the Davenport Tower & Residences (an expansion of [[The Davenport Hotel (Spokane)|The Davenport Hotel]]), no other high-rise has gone up in Spokane.
Other significant buildings in downtown include the [[Spokane Convention Center]], the [[First Interstate Center for the Arts]], and the [[Spokane Arena]].
==Geography== The topography of Riverside is mostly flat except for areas downstream of the Spokane Falls which are located in a canyon. South of Riverside slopes up to the South Hill, quite steeply in some places such as Pioneer Park, where long cliffs oriented east-west provide great views of Riverside, the North Side and [[Spokane Valley, Washington|Spokane Valley]] to the east.
Riverside straddles Sprague Avenue, which divides the city into North and South. On the eastern end of Riverside, Division Street splits the city into East and West. I-90 is elevated through almost all of downtown, often with parking lots underneath, but occasional blocks are solid cement, forming a barrier at the southern end of Riverside. Immediately south of the Interstate the high density area continues into a growing medical district with Spokane's two largest hospitals, [[Providence Sacred Heart Medical Center and Children's Hospital|Sacred Heart]] and [[Deaconess Hospital (Spokane, Washington)|Deaconess]].
To the west is one of Spokane's oldest and densest neighborhoods, Browne's Addition. In the photo, Browne's addition is the treed area in the foreground on the right. The left side of the foreground is the valley cut by the Spokane river immediately downstream of the falls; this is the small and similar neighborhood of Peaceful Valley.
[[Gonzaga University]] is located just upstream on the north side of the river from Riverside. Across the river from Gonzaga are the new University District home campuses of [[Eastern Washington University]] and [[Washington State University]]. Division Street separates Downtown from the University District.
==Rebirth and development==
[[Image:2008-1018-023-DavenportHotel-int1.jpg|thumb|right| Lobby of the Davenport Hotel]]
Riverside had undergone a major rebirth in the years before the recession, after the completion of the [[River Park Square Mall]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Welcome to Downtown Spokane| publisher = Downtown Spokane Partnership| url = http://www.downtownspokane.org/| accessdate = 2008-12-14}}</ref> The historic [[The Davenport Hotel (Spokane)|Davenport Hotel]] underwent a major renovation in 2002 after being vacant for over 20 years.<ref>{{cite web| title = Hotel History| publisher = The Davenport Hotel and Tower| url = http://www.thedavenporthotel.com/index.php?act=/history| accessdate = 2009-01-25}}</ref> The project was funded by local entrepreneur [[Walt Worthy]], who also added a Safari-themed 20 story tower to the hotel in 2007. Other major projects include the Holley Mason Building - seen as the catalyst to Riverside's rebirth, the building of the Big Easy concert house (now renamed the [[Knitting Factory]]), the remodeling of the historic [[Montvale Hotel]] and [[Fox Theatre (Spokane)|Fox Theater]] (now home to the [[Spokane Symphony]]), numerous new condo buildings, and renovations of historic, older brick buildings that will soon house both condos and business. Also, the [[Spokane Convention Center]] just finished a major expansion which helped host the [[2007 United States Figure Skating Championships|2007 US Figure Skating Championships]].<ref>{{cite web| title = About The Spokane Convention Center| publisher = Spokane Convention Center| url = http://www.spokanecenter.com/about.php| accessdate = 2009-01-15}}</ref>
==Districts and areas==
===Riverfront Park=== [[Image:Spokane Riverfront Park 20061014.jpg|thumb|right|The Great Northern clock tower and U.S. Pavilion in Riverfront Park]]
[[Riverfront Park (Spokane)|Riverfront Park]], created after Expo '74 and occupying the same site, is {{convert|100|acre|km2}} in Riverside and the site of some of Spokane's largest events.<ref name =Riverfront>{{cite web| title = About the Park| publisher = Riverfront Park| url = http://www.spokaneriverfrontpark.com/content.php?id=129| accessdate = 2009-01-25}}</ref> The park has views of the [[Spokane Falls]], and holds a number of civic attractions, including a Skyride that is a rebuilt gondola that carries visitors across the falls from high above the river gorge, a 5-story IMAX theater, and a small amusement park (which is converted into an ice-skating rink during the winter months) with numerous rides and concessions.<ref name =Riverfront/> The park is host to a full schedule of family entertainment and events such as the [[Lilac Bloomsday Run|Bloomsday]] Post-Race Celebration, [[Spokane Hoopfest|Hoopfest]], the [[IMAX]] Film Festival, Spokane Music Festival, Pig-Out in the Park, Restaurant Fair, Pow Wow, [[First Night]] Spokane, plus many outdoor concerts and other community activities. The Park also includes a hand-carved carousel created in 1909 by [[Charles I. D. Looff]] as a wedding present for his daughter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Natatorium Carousel/ Looff Carousel |publisher=City-County of Spokane Historic Preservation Office |url=http://www.historicspokane.org/NationalRegister/nat_carousel.htm |accessdate=2009-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610155117/http://www.historicspokane.org/NationalRegister/nat_carousel.htm |archivedate=June 10, 2008 }}</ref> The carousel still operates in Riverfront Park, where riders can participate in an old-time ring toss. The carousel continues to offer a free ride to the rider who grabs the brass ring. Riverfront Park also includes ample views of the Spokane falls as well as other water features (some man-made) of the Spokane River.
===Downtown Core=== [[File:SpokaneSkywalks.jpg|thumb]] The Downtown Core is the heart of Riverside and is generally considered to be the several block vicinity surrounding Spokane City Hall, River Park Square, the STA Plaza, and the Davenport Hotel. A majority of Spokane's high-rise buildings are located in this core area. Spokane's skywalk system also overlays the street grid and street life within the core, linking 14 blocks together. A number of downtown's retailers and restaurants are also located within the Downtown Core.
===Arts and Entertainment District=== Riverside's rich Entertainment District is home to some of the best restaurants, live entertainment venues, and hotels in Spokane. Located south and west of the Downtown Core, this area hosts many concerts, plays, galleries, and other shows. These events are hosted in a variety of venues including the Fox Theater, The Bing Crosby Theater, and The Knitting Factory.
The Arts and Entertainment District has a number of large historic buildings. Many of these buildings are hotels that have been beautifully renovated, and capture the charm of turn of the century Spokane. More recently, this area has become a hub for breweries. There are multiple tasting rooms between Lincoln and Cedar Street along First and Second Avenue, making it a popular destination for brewery tours.
===Convention Center District=== [[File:SpokaneConvCtr_CentennialTrail.jpg|thumb|left|The Centennial Trail runs through the Convention Center District between the Spokane River (pictured right) and the convention center (pictured left).]] The Convention Center District is situated to the east of the Downtown Core and is anchored by the [[Spokane Convention Center]] and [[First Interstate Center for the Arts]]. Its location is directly adjacent to Riverfront Park; an advantage that has been embraced through careful planning and architectural design of buildings in the district which allows the buildings to interface with the park, the river, and recreational trails (including the [[Spokane River Centennial Trail|Centennial Trail]]) that run along it. The district was born out of [[Expo '74]], which developed the original structure that ultimately became the IFirst Interstate Center for the Arts and the Spokane Convention Center. The convention center has been expanded several times since its original construction, stretching the bounds of the district farther east, where it ties into the University District.
Much of the other development around the Convention Center District stems from the Spokane Convention Center and the First Interstate Center for the Arts, including restaurants, retail, and hotels. Spokane's largest and tallest hotels, including the DoubleTree, Davenport Grand, and Red Lion Hotel at the Park are located in or immediately adjacent to the convention center district. The business types located around the Convention Center District provide a common overlap with businesses supporting the adjacent University District as well, helping to alleviate some of the "urban dead zones" that are all too commonly created when the convention centers - particularly large ones in major cities much larger than Spokane - are not in use.
===Kendall Yards=== Located along the southern edge of the West Central neighborhood just across the Spokane River from Downtown Spokane is Kendall Yards, a [[new urbanism|new urbanist]] community. Though not officially within the boundaries of Riverside, Kendall Yards plays a vital role in the culture and future of the downtown core by increasing the urban residential population in the immediate vicinity of it.
[[Image:Downtown Spokane WA on approach to the airport.jpg|left|thumb|Kendall Yards is an urban infill development; its site is pictured in the lower-left hand corner.]] The neighborhood is one of the largest [[infill|urban infill]] development projects in the city's history and has reclaimed a [[brownfield land|brownfield]] formerly occupied by [[rail yard]]s. The site of Kendall Yards used to be the main entry point of the railroad into Riverside before alterations to the downtown area in preparations for [[Expo '74]] relocated the railroads south of the Spokane River. The {{convert|78|acre|km2|sing=on}} site sat vacant from that point on for another three decades until 2005, when a brownfield cleanup<ref>[http://www.djc.com/news/en/11180868.html Spokane does brownfields on a grand scale]</ref> took place in preparations for the groundbreaking of the development. The cleanup, which won a [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|US EPA]] award, took approximately one year and removed over 223,000 tons of contaminated soil from the site.<ref>[http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2006/mar/29/railroad-cleanup-gets-epa-award/ Railroad cleanup gets EPA award]</ref>
The initial proposal for Kendall Yards called for 2,600 residences and 1 million square feet of commercial space, worth up to $1 billion. The development broke ground in 2007, however, the impending [[Great Recession]] bankrupted the project's developer before any buildings were constructed. The now cleaned-up site continued to sit vacant for another few years until a Spokane-based developer, Greenstone Corp., purchased the site in 2009 and began construction in 2010.<ref>[http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2010/apr/22/work-begins-kendall-yards-housing/ Work begins on Kendall Yards housing]</ref> In response to the economic conditions at the time, the original plans for the development were scaled back; the proposed density, residential unit count, and commercial square footage were all reduced to approximately one-half of the original scope. However, the scaled-back plans did have its advantages; the development was more likely to be successful, the more land would be available for open green space, and the reduced density would be more compatible with the existing fabric of the adjacent West Central neighborhood to the north. Construction of the development is phased and is expected to be ongoing through the mid-2020s.
[[File:Kendall-Yards Summit-Parkway1.jpg|right|thumb|A view down Summit Parkway in the business district of Kendall Yards. It is worthwhile to note the wide sidewalks, landscaped streets, and mix of building types, all consistent with new urbanist principles.]] Designed on [[new urbanism|new urbanist]] principles, the plan and makeup of the neighborhood emphasizes mixed-use development, diversity of densities and housing types, open space, and walkability. Much of the neighborhood consists of multi-family structures of townhomes, condominiums, and apartments. There are also single-family detached homes, community gardens, free-standing commercial buildings, and mixed-use buildings (with ground-floor retail and apartment units above). Green and recreational space is also emphasized; the community includes parks, sidewalks, and plazas and also completed a long-awaited infill section of the [[Spokane River Centennial Trail|Centennial Trail]], extending it from Downtown through the entire {{convert|78|acre|km2|sing=on}} site along the northern banks of the Spokane River Gorge.
===North Bank=== The North Bank area is located to the north of the Spokane River and Riverfront Park. It is home to a variety of uses including civic, residential, shopping, dining, and lodging. Destinations include the [[Spokane Arena]], the central YMCA/YWCA, Spokane Civic Theater, and Flour Mill. A number of businesses based on the North Bank are in the health, banking, hotel, and real estate industries.
==Cityscape== {{wide image|SpokaneDTPanorama.jpg|2000px|Panorama of Riverside (Downtown Spokane) looking north. Taken from the Deaconess Medical Center parking garage}}
==Surrounding Areas== *Browne's Addition *South Hill *University District
==See also== *[[Spokane, Washington]] *[[Neighborhoods in Spokane, Washington]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Spokane County, Washington]] *[[List of tallest buildings in Spokane]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.spokanenightscenes.com/presentation5.html Images of downtown Spokane, at night]
[[Category:Geography of Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:Neighborhoods in Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:Central business districts in the United States|Spokane]]

revision.comment: /* Alphabetical list of selected descendants of Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours */ I added the birth year of Eleuthère I. du Pont.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Family | name = Du Pont family | crest = [[File:Coat of Arms of Samuel Francis Du Pont.svg|200px]] | caption = [[Motto]]: "''Rectitudine sto''"
(Stand upright) | early_forms = du Pont de Nemours | origin = [[France]] | region = [[Delaware]] and [[Pennsylvania]], U.S. | ethnicity = [[French American]] | traditions = [[Roman Catholics]]
[[Reformed]] (''see [[Huguenots]]'')
[[Episcopal Church (USA)|Episcopalians]] | members = [[Sieur]] [[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]]
Admiral [[Samuel Francis Du Pont]]
[[John Eleuthère du Pont]]
Gov. [[Pierre S. du Pont IV]] | otherfamilies = * [[Astor family]] * [[Rockefeller family]] * [[Roosevelt family]] * [[Vanderbilt family]] | estates = [[Nemours Mansion and Gardens|Nemours]] ([[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]])
[[Louviers (Wilmington, Delaware)|Louviers]] (Wilmington)
[[Winterthur Museum, Garden and Library|Winterthur Mansion and Gardens]] ([[Winterthur, Delaware|Winterthur]]) | meaning = Du Pont, "Of the bridge" }} The '''Du Pont family''' ({{IPAc-en|dj|uː|ˈ|p|ɒ|n|t}})[http://www.dictionary.com/browse/dupont "DuPont"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''. is an [[United States|American]] family descended from [[Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours]] (1739–1817). Since the 19th century, the Du Pont family has been one of the richest families in America.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/du-pont/|title=Du Pont family|work=forbes.com|accessdate=9 October 2016}} Many former Du Pont family estates have been opened to the public as museums, gardens, or parks, such as [[Nemours Mansion and Gardens]], [[Longwood Gardens]], and [[Winterthur Museum, Garden and Library]]. The family's first American estate, located at [[Hagley Museum and Library]], has been designated a [[National Historic Landmark]]. In recent years, the family has continued to be known for its association with political and business ventures, as well as philanthropic efforts on behalf of various organizations such as [[The Jockey Club]],{{cite web|title=Lunger Estate Makes Major Contribution to Equine Research|url=http://www.jockeyclub.com/default.asp?section=Resources&area=0&archives=show&story=194|website=The Jockey Club|accessdate=18 April 2015}} the [[Philadelphia Orchestra]],{{cite news|last1=Duvoisin|first1=Marc|title=Family's Reach Influenced Business, Politics And Arts The Du Pont Family Can Take Some Credit For The Creation Of Longwood Gardens, The Atomic Bomb And Nylon Hosiery.|url=http://articles.philly.com/1996-01-28/news/25653867_1_du-pont-eleuthere-irenee-pont-iv|accessdate=18 April 2015|publisher=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=28 January 1996}} the [[Delaware Art Museum]], and the [[Grand Opera House (Wilmington, Delaware)|Grand Opera House]].{{cite web|last1=Nagengast|first1=Larry|title=The Past, Present and Future of DuPont|url=http://www.delawaretoday.com/Delaware-Today/April-2014/The-Past-Present-and-Future-of-DuPont/index.php?cparticle=7&siarticle=6#artanc|publisher=Delaware Today|accessdate=18 April 2015}} Two family members were the subjects of well-publicized criminal cases. Heir [[John Eleuthère du Pont]] was convicted of murdering wrestling coach [[Dave Schultz (wrestling)|Dave Schultz]] in 1996{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/10/sports/olympics/10dupont.html|title=John E. du Pont, Heir Who Killed an Olympian, Dies at 72|date=10 December 2010|publisher=|accessdate=9 October 2016|via=The New York Times}} and heir [[Robert H. Richards IV]] was convicted of raping his 3-year-old daughter in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/04/02/justice/delaware-du-pont-rape-case/index.html|title=Du Pont heir convicted of rape spared prison - CNN.com|first=By Kevin Conlon and Stephanie Gallman|last=CNN|work=cnn.com|accessdate=9 October 2016}} The family is depicted in the 2014 biographical film ''[[Foxcatcher]]'' with [[Steve Carell]] playing [[John Eleuthère du Pont]] and [[Vanessa Redgrave]] playing [[William du Pont, Jr.#Marriages, family, and career|Jean du Pont]], the wife of [[William du Pont, Jr.]] The family fortune as of 2016 was $14.3 billion with over 3,500 living members around the world, most of whom are only marginally related. ==History== [[Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours]] was the son of a Parisian watchmaker and a member of a [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundian]] [[Huguenot]] family, and descendant of a minor [[nobility|noble family]] on his mother's side. He and his sons, [[Victor Marie du Pont]] and [[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]], emigrated from France in 1800 to the United States and used the resources of their Huguenot heritage to found one of the most prominent of [[United States|American]] families, and one of its most successful [[corporation]]s, [[DuPont|E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company]], initially established by Éleuthère Irénée as a gunpowder manufacturer. In 1802, Éleuthère Irénée du Pont established a gunpowder mill on the banks of the [[Brandywine Creek (Christina River)|Brandywine River]] near [[Wilmington, Delaware]]. The location provided all the necessities to operate the mill: a water flow sufficient to power it, available timber (mainly willow trees) that could be turned into charcoal fine enough to use for gunpowder, close proximity to the [[Delaware River]] to allow for shipments of sulfur and saltpeter, the other ingredients used in the manufacture of gunpowder. There were also nearby stone quarries to provide needed building materials.{{cite web|url=http://americanroads.net/happy_trails.winter2014.htm|title=Happy Trails|work=americanroads.net|accessdate=9 October 2016}} Over time the [[DuPont|Du Pont company]] grew into the largest black powder manufacturing firm in the world. The family remained in control of the company up through the 1960s{{cite news|title=DuPont Co.'s 19 leaders since 1802|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/local/2015/10/05/duponts-leaders/73422578/|accessdate=27 October 2015|work=Wilmington News Journal}} and family trusts still own a substantial amount of the company's stock. This and other companies run by the Du Pont family employed up to 10 percent of Delaware's population at its peak.{{cite news|last1=Gross|first1=Scott|title=Delaware's dilemma: A fading DuPont|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/money/industries/2015/10/23/delawares-dilemma-fading-dupont/74329022/|accessdate=27 October 2015|work=Wilmington News Journal}} During the 19th century, the Du Pont family maintained their family wealth by carefully arranged marriages between [[inbreeding|cousins]][http://discovermagazine.com/2003/aug/featkiss Go Ahead, Kiss Your Cousin] by Richard Conniff, From the August 2003 issue, published online August 1, 2003 which, at the time, was the norm for many families. The family played a large part in politics during the 18th and 19th centuries and assisted in negotiations for the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Paris]] and the [[Louisiana purchase]]. Both [[T. Coleman du Pont|T. Coleman]] and [[Henry A. du Pont]] served as U.S. senators, and [[Pierre S. du Pont, IV]] served as Governor of Delaware. The family has also played an important role in historic preservation and land conservation, including helping to found the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]], preserving President [[James Madison]]'s home [[Montpelier (Orange, Virginia)|Montpelier]], and establishing numerous museums such as Winterthur and the [[Delaware Museum of Natural History]]. The Brandywine Conservancy founded by family member [[George Alexis Weymouth]] owns around {{convert|2350|acres|0|abbr=on}} of land in Pennsylvania and Delaware, and owns permanent conservation easements on an additional {{convert|37000|acres|0|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|last1=Bauers|first1=Sandy|title=Conservancy gains easement Winterthur's pastoral beauty is now protected|url=http://articles.philly.com/2002-07-25/news/25358114_1_winterthur-henry-f-du-pont-easement|accessdate=27 October 2015|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=25 July 2002}}{{cite news|last1=Montgomery|first1=Jeff|title=The Brandywine Conservancy: Preserving Nature, Art, and History|url=http://php.delawareonline.com/news/assets/2014/09/WIL_1001_BRANDYWINE_CONSERVANCY_.pdf|accessdate=27 October 2015|work=Wilmington News Journal}} In 2013, [[Lammot du Pont Copeland]]'s [[Mt. Cuba Center]] contributed over $20 million to purchase land for donation to the federal government to form the [[First State National Historical Park]].{{cite web|url=http://www.conservationfund.org/projects/woodlawn-property-a-new-national-park-in-delaware/|title=Delaware's First State National Monument|accessdate=6 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031235716/http://www.conservationfund.org/projects/woodlawn-property-a-new-national-park-in-delaware/|archivedate=31 October 2014|df=}} Beginning with [[William du Pont, Jr.]] and his sister, [[Marion duPont Scott]], many members of the Du Pont family have been involved in the breeding and racing of [[thoroughbred]] [[horse racing|racehorses]], as well as establishing racehorse venues and training tracks.{{cite web|url=http://emc.vetmed.vt.edu/emcmariondupontscott.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011227114730/http://emc.vetmed.vt.edu/emcmariondupontscott.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=27 December 2001|title=Marion duPont Scott Equine Medical Center|publisher=University of Vermont|accessdate=9 October 2016}} ==Spelling of the name== The stylings “Dupont”, “DuPont”, du Pont" and "Du Pont" for the family name have both been widely used in published writings. In many publications, the styling is "du Pont" when quoting an individual's full name and "Du Pont" when speaking of the family as a whole, although some individual Du Ponts have chosen to style it differently, such as [[Samuel Francis Du Pont]]. The name of the chemical company founded by the family is today styled solid as "[[DuPont]]" in the short form (but the long form is styled as E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company); the stylings "Du Pont" and "DuPont" for the company's short name coexisted in the 20th century, but the latter is now consistently used in the company's branding. The solid styling "duPont" is less common, but the [[Nemours Alfred I. duPont Hospital for Children]] uses it, as does the [[duPont Registry]]. William S. Dutton's mid-20th-century history of the family business{{Citation |last=Dutton |first=William S. |year=1942 |title=Du Pont: One Hundred and Forty Years |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WEtZAAAAYAAJ |lccn=42011897 |postscript=.}} uses "Du Pont" both for the family mentioned generally and for the company's short name but "du Pont" in an individual's full name (for example, "[[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]]", "[[Henry du Pont]]", "[[Alfred V. du Pont |Alfred Victor du Pont]]", "[[Lammot du Pont I|Lammot du Pont]]"); for example, "when he [Lammot du Pont] went to General Henry du Pont with the proposal that the Du Ponts manufacture dynamite, he was answered by a blunt and unqualified 'No!'"{{rp|116}}) The first page of Dutton's monograph{{rp|3}} contains the following footnote about the surname's styling (the mention of "Samuel Dupont" here refers to the 18th-century Parisian watchmaker, not to [[Samuel Francis Du Pont|his 19th-century descendant]]): "Samuel Dupont used this form of the family name [i.e., Dupont], but beginning in 1763 [[Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours|his son]] signed himself 'Du Pont.' Later, he added 'de Nemours' to his name to prevent confusion with two other Duponts in the [[Chamber of Deputies (France)|French Chamber of Deputies]]. Du Pont, in English, is pronounced with the accent on the second syllable. In French, neither syllable is accented."{{rp|3}} [[French orthography|French orthographic]] tradition for the styling of ''de'' (or its inflected forms) as a surname particle, in either nobiliary or non-nobiliary form, is discussed at ''[[Nobiliary particle#France|Nobiliary particle § France]]''. In non-nobiliary form, the prevalent French styling of the name is "[[Wiktionary:Dupont|Dupont]]", and thus the choice by Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours to begin styling himself so during the monarchical era hints at social ambition. But the influence of French orthography and prerevolutionary class structure on how [[English orthography]] styles surnames today is outweighed by how families and individuals so named style themselves. ==Alphabetical list of selected descendants of Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours== {{unreferenced section|date=November 2017}} Below is an alphabetical listing of selected notable members of the family. It is followed by a listing of their families in order of descent. The listing is intended only to illustrate the relationships among the notable members of the family and is not a complete genealogy. The only family groupings and lines of descent shown are those necessary to illustrate relationships for notable members of the family. By 1942 there were believed to be 705 direct descendants of [[Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours]], and in the 21st century there are well more than 2,000 living members of the family. {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[A. Felix du Pont|Alexis Felix du Pont]] (1879–1948) *[[A. Felix du Pont Jr.|Alexis Felix du Pont, Jr.]] (1905–1996) *Alexis Irénée du Pont (1816–1857) *[[Alfred I. du Pont|Alfred Irénée du Pont]] (1864–1935) *[[Alfred V. du Pont|Alfred Victor Philadelphe du Pont]] (1798–1856) *[[Amy Elizabeth du Pont]] (1875–1962) *[[Ben duPont|Benjamin Franklin du Pont]] (born 1964) *[[Charles I. du Pont|Charles Irénée du Pont]] (1797–1869) *[[Charles I. du Pont|Charles Irénée du Pont, II]] (1859–1902) *[[Coleman Dupont Donaldson]] (1922–2009) *[[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]] (1771–1834) *Éleuthère Irénée du Pont, II (1829–1877) *[[Eleuthère I. du Pont]] (1966-) *[[Ethel du Pont]] (1916–1965) *[[E. Paul du Pont|Éleuthère Paul du Pont]] (1887–1950) *[[Francis Gurney du Pont]] (1850–1904) *[[Francis I. du Pont|Francis Irénée du Pont]] (1873–1942) *[[George Alexis Weymouth]] (1936-2016) *[[Henry du Pont]] (1812–1889) *[[Henry A. du Pont|Henry Algernon du Pont]] (1838–1926) *[[Henry Francis du Pont]] (1880–1969) *[[Jane du Pont Lunger]] (1914–2001) *[[John Eleuthère du Pont|John Éleuthère du Pont]] (1938–2010) *[[Irénée du Pont]] (1876–1963) *[[Lammot du Pont I]] (1831–1884) *[[Lammot du Pont II]] (1880–1952) *[[Marion duPont Scott|Marion duPont]] (1894–1983) *[[Louise E. du Pont Crowninshield|Louise Evelina du Pont Crowninshield]] (1877–1958) *[[Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours]] (1739–1817) *[[Pierre S. du Pont]] (1870–1954) *[[Pierre S. du Pont, IV|Pierre S. "Pete" du Pont, IV]] (born 1935) *[[Richard Chichester du Pont]] (1911–1943) *[[Samuel Francis Du Pont]] (1803–1865) *[[T. Coleman du Pont|Thomas Coleman du Pont]] (1863–1930) *[[Victor Marie du Pont]] (1767–1827) *[[Victorine & Samuel Homsey|Victorine du Pont Homsey]] (1900–1998) *[[William du Pont]] (1855–1928) *[[William du Pont Jr.]] (1896–1965) *[[William du Pont III]] (1952–pres.) *[[Henry E.I du Pont]] (1927-2002.) *[[Martha Anne Caroline Verge du Pont (Muffin)]] (1928–2017) *[[Martha Ann "Charlotte" du Pont-McCartney]] (1942–pres.) *[[John du Pont Jr.]] (1944–pres.) *[[Sophie Madeline du Pont-McCartney]] (1990-pres.) *[[Martha Quinn Caroline du Pont]] (1930–pres.) *[[Martha Ann Caroline du Pont-Sessions]] (1940–pres.) *[[Dr. Katherine du Pont McCartney Livingston]] (1969–pres.) *[[Dr. John Peter McCartney Jr.]] (1972–pres.) *[[Dr. Elizabeth Charlotte McCartney-Winterbourne]] (1966–pres.) *[[Eliza Harrington-McCartney]] (1978–pres.) *[[John Rixey du Pont]] (1980–pres.) }} ==Family tree== The following list is not a complete [[genealogy]], but is ordered by descent to show the familial relationships between members of the du Pont family throughout history.
