{{Infobox President | name = Manuel Vicente | image = Manuel Vicente 2014.jpg | order = 2nd [[Vice President of Angola]] | president = [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] | predecessor = [[Fernando da Piedade Dias dos Santos]] | successor = [[Bornito de Sousa]] | term_start = 26 September 2012 | term_end = 26 September 2017 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|05|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Luanda, Angola|Luanda]], [[Portuguese Angola]] | alma_mater = [[Agostinho Neto University]] | spouse = Marinela Correia | children = 2 | party = [[Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola|MPLA]] }} '''Manuel Domingos Vicente''' (born 15 May 1956) is an [[Angola]]n politician who served as [[Vice President of Angola]] between September 2012 and September 2017. Previously he was [[chief executive officer]] of [[Sonangol]], Angola's state [[oil]] company, from 1999 to 2012, and he briefly served in the government as Minister of State for Economic Coordination in 2012. ==Early life and education== Born at [[Sambizanga]] neighborhood in [[Luanda]],[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5heK7Qua8qIbux7vZboYdX3UkMrBQ?docId=CNG.31f8de9a58d069f4c137be66715677b6.b1 "Sonangol's ex-boss styled as Dos Santos's heir apparent"], Agence France-Presse, 11 March 2012. his father was a shoemaker while his mother was a laundress. Vicente was raised by President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] eldest sister, Isabel Eduardo dos Santos.{{cite web|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/mundo/africa/angola/detalhe/manuel_vicente_o_delfim_que_foi_criado_pela_irma_de_eduardo_dos_santos|title=Manuel Vicente: o delfim que foi criado pela irmã de Eduardo dos Santos|language=Portuguese|date=25 February 2016|publisher=Negocios}} He received primary and secondary education at the São Domingos Mission School. However, his studies was interrupted by financial problems and he had to work as a locksmith and linotypist to help support the family.{{cite web|url=http://www.portalangop.co.ao/angola/pt_pt/mobile/noticias/politica/2012/8/39/Biografia-vice-presidente-Republica-Angola,0d03a6ee-a64a-472e-9ec5-c71c9f970d50.html|title=Biografia do vice-presidente da República de Angola|language=Portuguese|date=26 September 2012|publisher=Agência Angola Press}} He earned an [[electronic engineering]] degree at the [[Agostinho Neto University|University of Angola]] (Agostinho Neto University)Christophe Boisbouvier, [http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/JA2665p014-015.xml2/gouvernement-ministre-succession-jose-eduardo-dos-santosangola-manuel-vicente-l-homme-du-president-dos-santos.html "Angola : Manuel Vicente, l'homme du président dos Santos"], ''Jeune Afrique'', 8 February 2012 {{fr icon}}.Shrikesh Laxmidas, [https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE81007Y20120201?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true "Oilman Vicente waits in Angola presidential wings"], Reuters, 1 February 2012. in 1983. After working as a chief engineer during the 1980s, he headed the technical department of the Ministry of Oil from 1987 to 1991. He was appointed as Deputy Director-General of Sonangol, the state oil company, in 1991. In his professional training, Vicente had his degrees Substation and Transmission Lines, Furnas / Brazil-1985 Business Management of Petroleum, London, 1991, Marketing of Petroleum and its Derivatives, London-1991 Economics of Oil Operations - Petroleum Institute, London, 1991, Risk Analysis and Decision in the Oil Industry (OGCI) - Calgary 1992 petroleum Economics - (OGCI) - London 1992, among others connected to the oil industry.[http://www.portalangop.co.ao/angola/pt_pt/noticias/politica/2012/8/39/Biografia-vice-presidente-Republica-Angola,0d03a6ee-a64a-472e-9ec5-c71c9f970d50.html Biography of Vice President of the Republic of Angola] Angop (in Portuguese) He is the stepfather of a businessman, Mirco Martins. ==Political career== In 1999, Vicente was appointed as head of Sonangol. In that key post, he presided over the most important sector of the Angolan economy and was considered a close associate of President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]]. During his time in charge of the company, oil production increased dramatically. He routinely traveled abroad, acquiring "an excellent reputation from the international business community". Vicente was appointed as a member of the Political Bureau of the [[Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola]] (MPLA), the ruling party, in December 2009.[http://www.africaintelligence.com/AEM/who-s-who/2010/01/06/manuel-vicente,77688837-ART "Manuel Vicente"], ''Africa Energy Intelligence'', number 619, Africa Intelligence, 6 January 2010. A September 2011 report in ''Novo Jornal'' claimed that dos Santos intended for Vicente to be his successor. The report was followed by a flurry of speculation.[http://www.africa-confidential.com/article-preview/id/4148/Vicente_to_succeed_Dos_Santos "Vicente to succeed Dos Santos?"], ''Africa Confidential'', volume 52, number 18, 9 September 2011. Vicente was, however, reappointed for another term at the head of Sonangol in December 2011, briefly tempering the speculation. President dos Santos appointed Vicente as Minister of State for Economic Coordination on 30 January 2012;[http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/pt_pt/noticias/politica/2012/0/5/Presidente-Republica-nomeia-ministro-Estado-Coordenacao-Economica,c6a801f0-14b9-4791-90b4-8007f8274c9d.html "Presidente da República nomeia ministro de Estado da Coordenação Económica"], Angola Press Agency, 30 January 2012 {{pt icon}}. [[Francisco de Lemos José Maria]] succeeded Vicente at Sonangol. In line with earlier speculation, the move was generally interpreted by observers as suggesting that dos Santos was positioning Vicente as his eventual successor. It appeared that Vicente's government post would give him a great deal of authority in managing the economy, and it would bolster Vicente's credibility and experience given that he had previously only been involved in the oil industry. Nevertheless, it was believed that some other leading figures in the ruling party were skeptical about Vicente, given his relative inexperience in politics, and could be trying to resist the President's efforts to position him for the succession. [[Agence France-Presse]] reported in February 2012, citing an MPLA source, that Vicente would have the second spot on the MPLA's candidate list for the 2012 election, behind dos Santos, and would become [[Vice-President of Angola]] after the election.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gMM8fcD-SoSYfkYZ4BpqqKOfaydQ?docId=CNG.298ed147731872d4e6278091cab9c895.921 "Angola's Dos Santos to seek new term: party source"], Agence France-Presse, 11 February 2012. As anticipated, the MPLA Central Committee designated President dos Santos as head of the MPLA party list and Vicente as the second candidate on the list on 13 June 2012.[http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/en_us/noticias/politica/2012/5/24/President-Eduardo-dos-Santos-leads-party-list,b7b248c1-41a9-4c17-b7f2-883b9f8c3ed6.html "President Eduardo dos Santos leads party's list"], Angola Press Agency, 13 June 2012. The MPLA won the election, and Vicente took office as Vice President on 26 September 2012.[http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/en_us/noticias/politica/2012/8/39/Manuel-Vicente-inaugurated-Vice-president-Republic,6eeef65d-2009-485c-a9c1-52e4c7eb619e.html "Manuel Vicente inaugurated as Vice-president of Republic"], Angola Press Agency, 26 September 2012. In August 2014 Manuel Vicente participated, representing the Angolan Head of State, in the [[United States–Africa Leaders Summit]], an initiative of the American president, [[Barack Obama]], held in Washington DC under the theme "Investing in the future of Africa."[http://www.portalangop.co.ao/angola/en_us/noticias/politica/2014/7/31/Vice-President-attends-Africa-summit,91a709b3-4da4-4b55-bd75-3e4897100913.html Vice President attends US/Africa summit], Angolan Press Agency, August 2, 2014. Manuel Vicente was present at the 69th [[General Assembly of the United Nations]], which took place in September 2014 in [[New York City]]. The Angolan Vice-President defended a reform in the [[UN Security Council]], which, according to him, should “be more in line with the international context and reflect an equal geographical representation through the increase in the number of permanent members”, namely by including an African country. In his speech, the Angolan Vice-President also approached issues such as the resurgence of armed conflicts and the religious fundamentalism in some African countries, as well as the importance of disarmament and the combating of drug and human trafficking and transnational organized crime.[http://observador.pt/2014/09/29/angola-quer-africa-em-permanencia-conselho-de-seguranca/ Angola quer África em permanência no Conselho de Segurança] Observador (29-09-2014) In November 2014, Manuel Vicente was distinguished with the "Sirius Award" by the multinational corporation [[Deloitte]].[http://www.portalangop.co.ao/angola/en_us/noticias/politica/2014/10/48/Vice-president-gets-Sirius-Award,9b143885-bc73-4e5c-a4e7-0dd995bb0be5.html Vice President gets Sirius Award] Angola Press Agency, November 28, 2014. In December 2016, the MPLA chose [[João Lourenço]], the Minister of Defense and Vice-President of the MPLA, as the party's top candidate and therefore its presidential candidate for the [[Angolan legislative election, 2017|2017 election]]. Lourenço, and not Vicente, was thus expected to succeed dos Santos as President.Herculano Coroado, [https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFKBN13S06T?sp=true "Angola's Dos Santos not up for re-election in 2017 -party document"], Reuters, 3 December 2016. ==Controversy== In June 2017, a Portuguese court ruled that Vincente should face trial over bribery allegations brought against him by a prosecutor in February 2017 after accused of bribing a magistrate with $810,000 in order to shelve investigations into his deals at an oil company named [[Sonangol Group]] which he headed between 2009 and 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/06/22/angolan-vice-president-must-face-portuguese-corruption-charges-court-rules/|title=Angolan Vice President should face Portuguese corruption charges: court rules|publisher=Africanews|date=22 June 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Angola|Energy}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Fernando da Piedade Dias dos Santos|Fernando da Piedade
Dias dos Santos]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Vice President of Angola]]|years=2012–2017}} {{s-aft|after=[[Bornito de Sousa]]}} {{s-end}} {{Government ministers in Angola}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vicente, Manuel}} [[Category:Angolan businesspeople]] [[Category:Agostinho Neto University alumni]] [[Category:Businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Vice Presidents of Angola]] [[Category:Angolan politicians]] [[Category:People from Luanda]] [[Category:Petroleum in Angola]] [[Category:21st-century Angolan people]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=November 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Abiyev Marat Zhaksylykovich |image = Марат Абиев.jpg |occupation = Businessman, writer |birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1989|09|06}} |birth_place = [[Kandyagash]], [[Aktobe Region]], [[Republic of Kazakhstan]] |citizenship = [[Republic of Kazakhstan]] |parents = Abiyev Zhaksylyk Medihatovich,
Tamara Abiyeva Asauhanovna }} '''Marat Zhaksylykovich Abiyev''' ({{lang-kz|Әбиев Марат Жақсылықұлы}} born September 6, 1989) is a Kazakh businessman, author of the Kazakhstani Dream book. He is the youngest millionaire, according to the Forbes Kazakhstan magazine, Marat Abiyev's net worth is estimated at US$11 million as of November 2013. Under Abiyev's leadership and due to efforts of his professional team of young professionals, Kazakhstani pipe products have been recognized and purchased by almost 80% of Kazakhstan's subsoil users. == Biography == Abiyev was born on September 6, in [[Kandyagash]], [[Aktobe Region]], [[Republic of Kazakhstan]]. In 1999, due to [[1998 Russian financial crisis|the economic crisis of 1998]], the Abiyev family moved to the regional center of [[Aktobe]].{{cite news|url=http://www.kazpravda.kz/ida.php?ida=43951 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140203055429/http://www.kazpravda.kz/ida.php?ida=43951 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-02-03 |title=Марат АБИЕВ: Не сдавайтесь! Будьте верны себе! |publisher=''// Казахстанская правда''—November 22, 2013 |author=''Рысты АЛИБЕКОВА'' }} === Family === Abiyev Zhaksylyk Medihatovich, the father, graduated from [[Kazakh Polytechnic Institute named after V.I. Lenin]] now called Satbayev Kazakh National Technical University, majoring in machinery and equipment for Oil and Gas Industry. He worked with such organizations as: Aktobe oil exploration, geophysical expedition in the position of a diesel engineman; Oktyabrskoe Drilling Operations Institution in the positions of a mechanic and shop superintendent; Central Operational Support Base in the position of the chief engineer; TOO KKBK Velikaya Stena in the position of the shop superintendent; In recent years he worked as the deputy commander for operations at the VPFO Ak Beren Central Headquarters Professional Uniformed Emergency Services State Enterprise in the rank of lieutenant colonel. Abiyeva Tamara Asauhanovna, the mother, is a teacher at the university on the Architecture and building construction course, [[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic|the Kazakh SSR]] chess champion. Zhaksylyk Marzhangul Zhaksylykovna, a sister, is a full-time student at Kazakh Humanities and Law Institute of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Kazakhstan (KAZGUU). After graduating from high school, he entered the Aktobe Cooperative College majoring in automated systems for information processing and management. He graduated from Aktobe Cooperative College in 2009. In 2002 he started working in network marketing. From 2003 to 2005 he was a producer of various Aktobe's rap bands. In 2004 he founded the company called ''AAA Technology'' which was engaged in servicing computers and office supplies.{{cite news|url = http://forbes.kz/process/businessmen/kak_aktyubinskiy_paren_k_23_godam_zarabotal_11_mln | title= Как актюбинский парень к 23 годам заработал $11 млн|publisher=''// Forbes Kazakhstan''—2013|author=''Ардак Букеева''}} In 2007 M.Z. Abiyev started working as an entrepreneur. He started two companies, one called ''W'' and the other one called IT-outsourcing. The ''W'' company was a web-based studio which was engaged in creation, design, and maintenance of websites. It was one of the first companies in the Aktobe region offering website services. ''W'' Web Studio won ''the Best in the service sector medal-award''. The company offered full and partial support of the activity, as well as the maintenance and modernization of IT infrastructure of various companies. In 2009, Marat created ''LLP Euromobile Kazakhstan'', the main focus of the company was the provision of satellite-based monitoring of vehicles. In 2011, Marat founded LLP KSP Steel Trading House. KSP Steel Trading House was created in order to increase sale volumes of [[KSP Steel|LLP KSP Steel]] which was the only producer of seamless steel pipes for subsoil users and businesses operating in the oil and gas industry in the Republic of Kazakhstan. Due to successful LLP KSP Steel Trading House's activity, Kazakhstani pipe products have been recognized. And almost 80% of the Republic of Kazakhstan subsoil users started buying products offered by LLP KSP Steel. Previously subsoil users of Kazakhstan would only purchase goods from foreign suppliers. KSP Steel Trading House got all the rewards it deserved. This included ''Best in the area of Products'' medal, ''Choose Kazakhstani products award'', and ''Europe – Asia – Cooperation without Borders'' medal. The establishment of ''the Association of Producers of Kazakhstan'' association of legal entities was initiated by him in 2012. The main mission of the Association is to "protect and promote domestic producers." Abiyev is also the founder of various companies in the UK and the Russian Federation. Some of these companies are engaged in the sale of goods produced in the Republic of Kazakhstan. Others are involved in international trade for the supply of the metal, food and medical equipment to the Islamic Republic of Iran from the United Kingdom, the Russian Federation, Turkey, People's Republic of China and Belarus. == Bibliography == * "[[Kazakhstan's Dream]]" (2013) == Net worth == According to the Forbes Kazakhstan magazine, Marat Abiyev's net worth is estimated at 11 million U.S. dollars as of November 2013 == Notes == * Kapital.kz Business Portal named Abiyev Marat person of the year in 2013.{{cite news|url = http://kapital.kz/gosudarstvo/25154/persony-2013-goda.html | title= Персоны 2013 года|publisher=''// Kapital.kz''—December 31, 2013}} The following people have also been named person of 2013: [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]], [[Grigory Marchenko]], [[Kenges Rakishev]] and Mikhail Lomtadze. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abiyev, Marat}} [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kazakhstani businesspeople]] [[Category:Kazakhstani writers]] [[Category:People from Aktobe Region]]

revision.comment: /* Career */replaced: Chairman → chairman, Board of Directors → board of directors, Board → board using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Marwan Hayek |image = Marwan.Hayek.jpg | caption = Marwan Hayek in 2012 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1969|9|7}} |birth_place = Beirut, Lebanon |known_for = [[Orascom Telecom]] Alfa Telecom | occupation = Chairman and CEO of Alfa Telecom | residence =[[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]] | education = [[Telecommunications]]
[[Electrical Engineering]]
[[Management]]
[[Finance]] |other_names = |spouse = |alma_mater = [[Faculté polytechnique de Mons]] |nationality = Lebanese |website = }} '''Marwan Hayek''' is the [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[Alfa (Lebanon)|Alfa]] Telecom in [[Lebanon]]. {{cite web |date = 24 January 2010 |title = Alfa Telecom Management Team |publisher = Alfa Telecom |url = https://www.alfa.com.lb/aboutus/companyinfo.aspx |accessdate = 29 January 2011 }} Born 7 September 1969, Hayek is a telecoms executive and digital economy specialist who was part of the team that built the first [[GSM]] network in [[Lebanon]].{{cite web |url=https://www.thebusinessyear.com/lebanon-2012/the-next-step/interview |title=The Next Step |date=January 2012 |work=The Business year |publisher=TBY |access-date=29 January 2016}} Marwan has over 18 years experience in the telecom sector across the [[MENA]] region. ==Education== Hayek holds a master's degree in [[Telecommunications]] and [[Electrical Engineering]] from the [[Faculte Polytechnique de Mons]] in Belgium. He attended and participated in several technical, IT and Management trainings including CCL, MEIRC, HEC, [[INSEAD]], [[MIT]] & [[Harvard]].{{cite web |url=https://superbitar.wordpress.com/tag/ceo/ |title=Marwan Hayek, Alfa’s New Chairman & CEO |date=April 2010 |work=Lebanon Opportunities |publisher=Infopro sal. |access-date=29 January 2016}} ==Career== Hayek started his career with [[France Telecom]] in Lebanon – Cellis, known currently as Alfa, where he was part of the initial team that built the first GSM network in Lebanon, before joining later on the [[Orascom Telecom Holding]] in 1999.{{cite web |url=https://www.thebusinessyear.com/lebanon-2012/wired-up/vip-interview |title=Wired Up |date=July 2012 |work=The Business year |publisher=TBY |access-date=29 January 2016}} Hayek has held several assignments within the Orascom Telecom Group’s subsidiaries and its Holding, the latest before his current appointment was in September 2007, where he joined [[Mobinil]] - Egypt as VP Technology in charge of both network and IT infrastructure. Prior to Mobinil, Hayek was the CTO of [[Mobilink]] in [[Pakistan]] (an OTH subsidiary) between June 2003 and September 2007. Between 2000 and 2002, Hayek was part of the team who built [[Sabafon]]’s network in [[Yemen]] in the position of CTO. Under Hayek, OTH grew to over 120M subscribers. Hayek took the helm of [[Alfa (Lebanon)|Alfa]], the first Lebanese mobile operator managed by [[Orascom Telecom]], as its chairman and CEO, since the beginning of March 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.arabcommunications.com/dialDetails.asp?id=1&catid=35|title=Interview with Marwan Hayek - CEO and Chairman of ALFA |date=8 August 2011 |work=Arab Communication Consult |publisher=ACC |access-date=29 January 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.telecomreviewna.com/index.php/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=315:telecom-review-summit-draws-world-telecom-leaders&catid=45:january-2013&Itemid=90 |title=Telecom Review Summit Draws World Telecom Leaders |date=15 January 2013 |work=Telecom Review |publisher=Trace Media |access-date=29 January 2016}} He led the introduction of the 3G+{{cite web |url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Business/Lebanon/2011/Oct-26/152215-alfa-launches-long-awaited-3g-services-for-mobile-phone-clients.ashx |title=Alfa Launches Long-Awaited 3G Services |date=26 October 2011 |work=The Daily Star |publisher=Daily Star |access-date=29 January 2016}} technology that was first launched in October 2011{{cite web |url=http://www.marcopolis.net/alfa-lebanon-on-telecom-sector-3g-and-regulations.htm |title=Alfa Lebanon on Lebanese Telecom Sector, 3G and Regulations |date=24 September 2012 |work=Marcopolis |publisher=Marcopolis, LLC |access-date=29 January 2016}} as well as the introduction of 4G-LTE technology in May 2013. The Lebanese internet cable networks do not currently support fibre optics and the introduction of 3G+ followed by 4G-LTE gave access to the Lebanese people to high-speed internet.{{cite web |url=http://www.mediame.com/en/news/digital_media/lebanese_telecom_sector_supports_rapid_growth_digital_market |title=Lebanese Telecom Sector Supports The Rapid Growth Of The Digital Market |date=17 March 2013 |work=Arab Net |publisher=Media ME |access-date=29 January 2016}} Since 1999, following the winning of the Management Agreement of Alfa by Orascom Telecom in February 2009 and in addition to his position at Mobinil, Hayek was appointed on the board of MIC1-Lebanon and Orascom Telecom Lebanon. Since November 2014, he also sits at the board of directors of WIS Telecom (an OTMT international carrier subsidiary operating out of Belgium and Italy). The mobile penetration rate in Lebanon is close to saturation, indexed at 94% as per beginning year 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.telecomreview.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=1964 |title=Moving To The Next Level Through Digital Transformation |date=1 February 2016 |work=Telecom Review |publisher=Telecom Review |access-date=3 February 2016}} == Political Controversy == In 2015 there was a controversy where the Governmental Tender Office claimed that Hayek did not submit the tender for the renewal of Alfa's governmental regulated contract on time and the Prime Minister's office disqualified Orascom from taking part in the bidding. The [[Shura Council]] cancelled the decision and ordered the Tender Office to endorse the company’s application. The council also urged it to conduct a public and equally competitive bid.{{cite web |url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Business/Local/2015/Oct-07/318026-decision-banning-alfa-operator-from-telecom-tenders-annulled.ashx |title=Decision Banning Alfa Operator From Telecom Tenders Annulled |date=7 October 2015 |work=The Daily Star |publisher=The Daily Star |access-date=29 January 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.businessnews.com.lb/cms/Story/StoryDetails.aspx?ItemID=5167 |title=Alfa’s Orascom To Rejoin Telecom Tender |date=8 October 2015 |work=Business News |publisher=InfoPro sal. |access-date=29 January 2016}} The telecom operators in Lebanon are government regulated and have to go back to the Minister of Telecommunications whenever they want to invest in the network.{{cite web |url=http://www.commsmea.com/13744-eye-on-lebanon/ |title=Eye On Lebanon |date=25 September 2013 |work=The CommsMEA |publisher=ITP Business Publishing Ltd. |access-date=29 January 2016}} ==Awards and recognition== Hayek has received several awards in recognition of his contributions to the telecom sector’s development in [[Lebanon]] and the MENA region. In June 2011, he was awarded the Pan Arab “Telecommunications Man of the Year” title by the “Pan Arab Web Awards Academy.”{{cite web |url=http://www.blog.africantelecomsnews.com/2011/06/marwan-hayek-is-telecommunications-man.html |title=Marwan Hayek is ‘Telecommunications Man of the Year’ (Lebanon) |date=15 June 2011 |work=Mark Thomas |publisher=African Telecom News |access-date=29 January 2016}} In 2012, he received the “Visionary Entrepreneur Award” at the Business Forum 2012{{cite web |url=https://www.alfa.com.lb/aboutus/Awards.aspx?y=2012 |title=Alfa Telecom Awards And Achievements |date=15 June 2012 |work=Alfa Telecom |publisher=Alfa Telecom News |access-date=29 January 2016}} and he was awarded the “Golden Order of Merit for Leadership" from the “Arab Administrative Development Organization” (ARADO), an affiliate of the [[League of Arab States]], and “Tatweej” Academy.{{cite web |url=http://www.telecomreview.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=535:alfa-chairman-and-ceo-marwan-hayek-receives-golden-order-of-merit-for-leadership-award-from-the-arab-administrative-development-organization |title=Marwan Hayek Receives Golden Order of Merit |date=13 November 2012 |work=Telecom Review |publisher=Telecom Review |access-date=29 January 2016}} For contributions to the advancement of Lebanon’s digital economy, Hayek was awarded the “Golden Award for Leadership in Digital Economy” from “Tatweej” Academy.{{cite web |url=http://www.tatweej.org/ar/main.php |title=Tatweej Official Website}} He was awarded the “International Hisham Jaroudi Championship” trophy for support of sports development in Lebanon.{{cite web |url=http://executive-bulletin.com/business/telecoms/alfa-ceo-and-chairman-receives-al-riyadi-club-president-at-the-head-of-a-womens-team-delegation-that-presented-him-with-the-17th-arab-clubs-championship-for-women-and-the |title=Alfa CEO Receives Al Riyadi Club President |date=15 December 2015 |work=Executive Bulletin |publisher=Executive Magazine |access-date=29 January 2016}} ==Personal life== Hayek is married, with three children and lives in Beirut, Lebanon. He speaks Arabic, English and French. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://twitter.com/marwan_hayek Marwan Hayek's Twitter] * [https://www.alfa.com.lb Alfa Telecom's Official Website] {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hayek, Marwan}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Lebanese chief executives]] [[Category:Lebanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Orascom Group]] [[Category:Businesspeople in telecommunications]]

{{Infobox Officeholder |image = | honorific-prefix = | name = Mercurio J. "Merc" Martinez, Jr. | honorific-suffix = | imagesize = | small| caption = | order = | office = [[County Judge]] of [[Webb County, Texas|Webb County]], [[Texas]] | term_start = January 1, 1991 | term_end = December 31, 2001 | predecessor = Andres "Andy" Ramos | successor = [[Louis H. Bruni]] | constituency = [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]], [[Rio Bravo, Texas|Rio Bravo]], [[El Cenizo, Texas|El Cenizo]], [[Aguilares, Texas|Auilares]], [[Botines, Texas|Botines]], [[Bruni, Texas|Bruni]], [[Callaghan, Texas|Callaghan]], [[Darwin, Texas|Darwin]], [[Islitas, Texas|Islitas]], [[La Presa, Texas|La Presa]], [[Laredo Ranchettes, Texas|Laredo Ranchettes]], [[Larga Vista, Texas|Larga Vista]], [[Las Tiendas, Texas|Las Tiendas]], [[Los Ojuelos, Texas|Los Ojuelos]], [[Mirando City, Texas|Mirando City]], [[Oilton, Texas|Oilton]], [[Pescadito, Texas|Pescadito]], [[Ranchitos Las Lomas, Texas|Ranchitos Las Lomas]], [[Santo Tomás, Texas|Santo Tomás]], and [[Webb, Texas|Webb]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1937|7|25}} | birth_place =[[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]], Webb County, Texas | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | nationality = [[Mexican American]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] | spouse = Rosa Ancira Martinez (married 1959) | children = Six children:
Leticia, Adriana, Mercurio, III, Jorge, Carlos, and Rosalycia | parents =Mercurio, Sr., and Cristina Treviño Martinez | relations = | residence = Laredo, Texas | alma_mater = [[Saint Augustine High School (Laredo, Texas)|St. Augustine High School]]
[[Laredo Community College|Laredo Junior College]]
[[St. Mary's University, Texas|St. Mary's University]]
[[University of North Texas]] | occupation =[[Educator]]; [[Banker]] | profession = | religion =[[Roman Catholicism]] | signature = | website = | branch = | footnotes = }} '''Mercurio J. Martinez, Jr.''', often known as '''Merc Martinez''' (born July 25, 1937), is an educator, [[ranch]]er, and [[business]]man from his native [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]], [[Texas]]. From 1991 to 2002, he was the [[County Judge]] of [[Webb County, Texas|Webb County]] in [[South Texas]]. ==Background== Martinez was one of two children born at the age of sixty-three to Mercurio Martinez, Sr. (1876-1965), and his third wife, the 42-year-old former Cristina Treviño. The senior Martinez was a descendant of [[Spain|Spanish]]-[[Mexico|Mexican]] pioneers who had settled on the banks of the [[Rio Grande River]] in the mid-eighteenth century. An educator and public official in his native [[Zapata County, Texas|Zapata County]], Martinez subsequently practiced law in Laredo until 1942, when he retired at the age of sixty-six. He continued to associate with other lawyers on occasional cases dealing with land ownership and engaged in historical research.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/tamucush/00083/tamu-00083.html|title=Inventory of the Mercurio Martinez Papers|publisher=[[Texas A&M University]]|accessdate=April 28, 2014}} The younger sister of Martinez, Jr., is named Rosa, which is also the name of his wife, the former Rosa Ancira, whom he married in 1959. Mercurio and Rosa Martinez have six children, Leticia, Adriana, Mercurio, III, Jorge, Carlos, and Rosalycia. Martinez, Jr., was reared in the downtown La Azteca neighborhood of Laredo and graduated from [[Saint Augustine High School (Laredo, Texas)|St. Augustine High School]], then located downtown in the [[San Agustin de Laredo Historic District]] adjacent to the [[Cathedral of San Agustin (Laredo, Texas)|Cathedral of San Agustin]]. He studied at [[Laredo Community College|Laredo Junior College]], renamed in 1993 as [[Laredo Community College]]. He was exempt from [[conscription]] in the 1960s because he was a married father.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/voces/template-stories-indiv.html?work_urn=urn%3Autlol%3Awwlatin.717&work_title=Martinez%2C+Mercurio|title=Vidushi Shrimali, "Mercurio Martinez, Jr."|publisher=lib.utexas.edu|accessdate=April 28, 2014}} From 1968 to 1978, Martinez was trustee of LJC and its parent organization, the [[Laredo Independent School District]]. This was an era where the "Patron Party" ruled all local governmental entities providing political favors in return for loyalty and votes.{{cite book|last1=Piñon|first1=Fernando|title=Patron Democracy|date=1985|publisher=Contraste}} He has served since 2004 on the elected LCC board. He received his [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] in 1959 from [[St. Mary's University, Texas|St. Mary's University]] in [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]]. He procured a [[Master of Business Administration]] degree from the [[University of North Texas]] in [[Denton, Texas|Denton]]. He did post-graduate study at [[Southern Methodist University]] near [[Dallas]], [[Colorado State University]] in [[Fort Collins, Colorado|Fort Collins]], and the [[Harvard University School of Business]]. Martinez was an LJC business and economics instructor from c. 1960 until 1967, when he joined Union National Bank of Laredo, since [[Wells Fargo]] near City Hall."2014 honoree: Mercurio Martinez, Jr.: Former councilman, county judge to receive higher education award for community work," ''[[Laredo Morning Times]]'', February 6, 2014, p. 4D. ==Political life== In 1978, Martinez was elected to the Laredo City Council, a nominally [[nonpartisan]] position. At the same time, [[Aldo Tatangelo]] was elected [[mayor]] to succeed the retiring [[J. C. Martin (Texas politician)|J. C. "Pepe" Martin]] of the former "Independent Club" or "Patron Party", who subsequently spent time in the Webb County Jail for theft of municipal services.{{cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/wmiqt|title=Independent Club|publisher=''[[The Handbook of Texas]]''|accessdate= April 27, 2012}} Martinez worked on the council to change the city government from "strong mayor" to "weak mayor" format through a new municipal charter. After a brief time on the council, he was asked by [[U.S. President]] [[Jimmy Carter]], a fellow [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], to head the Southwest Regional Office in Dallas of the [[Small Business Administration]]. During this stint, he lived in Dallas on weekdays but returned to Laredo most weekends. In 1982, Martinez returned to Laredo to run for mayor against Tatangelo, and though he had led in the primary, he lost in the [[runoff election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tamiu.edu/oatah/rmendiola/documents/MercurioMartinezJr..pdf|title=Mercurio Martinez, Jr.|publisher=tamiu.edu|accessdate=April 28, 2014}} Martinez was "considered the best Old Party (Patron) candidate to reclaim the mayorship" in Fernando Piñon's book titled Patron Democracy. In 1990, he was elected county judge, having unseated the incumbent Andres "Andy" Ramos. Though he had no [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] opponent in the [[general election]], former Mayor Tatangelo, at the age of seventy-seven, opposed his former mayoral rival Martinez for county judge as a [[write-in]] candidate. Martinez still prevailed with some 75 percent of the votes cast, but the county Republican leadership, headed by [[Esther Buckley]], endorsed Tatangelo. After three terms as county judge, Martinez was unseated in the 2002 Democratic primary by [[Louis H. Bruni]], a former member of the Laredo City Council from District 2. Thereafter, beginning in the fall of 2003, Martinez began teaching accounting at [[Texas A&M International University]] in Laredo.Louis H. Bruni served only one term as county judge, having been defeated in 2006 by [[Danny Valdez]], who was himself defeated after two terms by former professional [[baseball]] player [[Tano Tijerina]] in 2014. In 2006, Martinez ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination to represent Texas House District 42, having been defeated by the incumbent and still serving [[Richard Raymond (Texas politician)|Richard Raymond]] of Laredo. In the primary Raymond fell .07 percent plus one vote short of an outright victory. He finished first with 11,806 votes (49.8 percent); Martinez trailed with 7,650 (32.3 percent). Two other contenders held the remaining 17.9 percent of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist.exe |title=2006 Democratic Party Primary Election: 3/7/2006 |publisher=elections.sos.state.tx.us |accessdate=April 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109062336/http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist.exe |archivedate=January 9, 2014 |df= }} In the runoff in April 2006, Raymond prevailed, 8,828 votes (57.8 percent) to 6,456 (42.2 percent).{{cite web|url=http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist.exe |title=Democratic Party Primary Runoff Election Results |date=April 11, 2006 |publisher=Texas Secretary of State |accessdate=April 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109062336/http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/elchist.exe |archivedate=January 9, 2014 |df= }} Oddly, in 2005, Martinez contributed $1,000 to Raymond's proposed run for the [[United States House of Representatives]], a race that never materialized.{{cite web|url=http://www.city-data.com/elec2/06/elec-LAREDO-TX-06.html|title=LAREDO, Texas (TX) Political Contributions by Individuals|publisher=city-data.com|accessdate=May 3, 2014}} In 2016, Martinez ran for reelection for the Laredo Community College board of trustees and was challenged by educator, author, and political activist Justin Allen Hundsnurscher. He won reelection with 61.89% of the vote or 28,723 votes against Hundsnurscher's 17,687 votes.{{cite web|url=https://www.laredo.edu/cms/LCC/News_and_Events/News/ImageRotation/content/2016/Nov/Election_results/ |title=LCC Board of Trustees 2016 Election Results }} In 2017, the still staunchly Democratic Martinez emerged as one of the first persons in Webb County to endorse [[Beto O'Rourke]], the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. representative]] for [[Texas' 16th congressional district]], who expects to challenge Republican [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Cruz]] in the general election scheduled for [[United States Senate election in Texas, 2018|November 6, 2018]]. Martinez claimed that Cruz has "alienated the majority of the senators ... We cannot afford somebody that has alienated the Senate that way. I've always felt that politics is the act of compromise. Let's reach a middle ground. In my opinion, Beto O'Rourke has that ability." Martinez said at a campaign stop that he sees no reason why O'Rourke won't match [[John F. Kennedy]]'s 90 percent margin in Webb County in the [[U.S. presidential election, 1960|1960 presidential election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lmtonline.com/local/politics/article/U-S-congressman-Beto-O-Rourke-returns-to-11723174.php|author=Julia Wallace|title=U.S. Congressman Beto O’Rourke returns to Laredo, hits up Palenque Grill|publisher=''Laredo Morning Times''|date=August 1, 2017|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} ==Honors== In 2014, Martinez was honored with the "Higher Education Award" by the [[League of United Latin American Citizens]], formally presented as part of the [[Washington's Birthday Celebration]] in Laredo. He is a past recipient of the [[Paul P. Harris|Paul Harris]] Award from [[Rotary International]], the St. George and Silver Beaver medals from the [[Boy Scouts of America]], the Tejano Achiever Award from LULAC, and "Distinguished Alumni" in 2001 of Laredo Community College.{{cite web|url=http://www.laredoisd.org/departments/tds/cabm.html|title=Mercurio Martinez|publisher=[[Laredo Independent School District]]|accessdate=April 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140129202511/http://www.laredoisd.org/departments/tds/cabm.html|archivedate=January 29, 2014|df=}} Martinez's namesake grandson, Mercurio Martinez, IV, was killed in an automobile accident in 2009 at the age of eighteen. Each year the community honors his memory with the "Mercurio Martinez, IV Teens in the Driver Seat, Annual 5K Run", sponsored by the [[Vidal M. Trevino School of Communications and Fine Arts|Vidal M. Treviño School of Communications and Fine Arts]], an entity of the Laredo Independent School District named for the late educator and [[Texas House of Representatives|State Representative]] [[Vidal M. Treviño]].{{cite web|url=http://www.laredoisd.org/board/nelsonsnotes/pics%20final/5k%20registration%20form%202013.pdf|title=Mercurio Martinez, IV Teens in the Driver Seat, 5th Annual 5K Run, Sunday March 24, 2013|publisher=laredoisd.org|accessdate=April 28, 2014}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Texas|Politics|Liberalism|Education|Business and Economics|Christianity}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{succession box | before=Andres "Andy" Ramos| title=[[County Judge]] of [[Webb County, Texas|Webb County]] (based in [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]], [[Texas]]) Mercurio J. "Merc" Martinez, Jr. |years=1991–2002| after=[[Louis H. Bruni]]}} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martinez, Mercurio}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Laredo, Texas]] [[Category:Laredo Community College alumni]] [[Category:St. Mary's University, Texas alumni]] [[Category:University of North Texas alumni]] [[Category:Texas A&M International University faculty]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:School board members in Texas]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:Ranchers from Texas]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Texas city council members]] [[Category:County judges in Texas]] [[Category:Texas Democrats]] [[Category:American politicians of Mexican descent]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:People associated with the Boy Scouts of America]] [[Category:People from Zapata County, Texas]] [[Category:Catholics from Texas]]

{{Infobox Person | name = Miloud Chaabi | image = Miloud Chaabi.jpg | image_size = 220px | birth_name = ميلود الشعبي | birth_date = 15 September, 1930 | birth_place = [[Essaouira]], Morocco | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|04|16|1930|09|15|df=yes}} | death_place= [[Hamburg]], Germany | occupation = {{hlist|Businessman|politician}} | known_for = {{nowrap|Wealthiest person in Morocco in 2011}} | net_worth = $800 million (2015) | children = 3 }} '''Miloud Chaabi''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]:ميلود الشعبي; September 15, 1930 – April 16, 2016) was a [[Shilha people|Chleuh-]][[Berbers|Berber]] [[Moroccan people|Moroccan]] businessman and politician who had an estimated net worth of $800 million in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/africa-billionaires/list/#tab:overall|title=Africa’s Billionaires|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-09-12|language=en}}</ref> He was the founder of [[Ynna Holding]] and the owner of the [[Riad Mogador]] hotel chain and group of supermarkets [[Aswak Assalam]] in Morocco. He was known for his strong stance against [[alcohol]] which is banned from both his hotel chain and supermarkets. His daughter, [[Asma Chaâbi]] has been mayor of the city of Essaouira from 2003 to 2009, and was the first woman to hold such a position in Morocco.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.alyaoum24.com/259672.html|title=أسماء الشعبي تخلف والدها الملياردير في البرلمان|access-date=2017-09-12|language=ar}}</ref><ref>http://www.alkhabar.ma/%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%A9%D8%8C-%D8%A5%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%A3%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%B1%D8%A3%D8%B3-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AC%D9%84%D8%B3-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%8A-%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%83%D8%B4_a6561.html</ref> His son, Mohcine, is a current member of the House of Representatives,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.febrayer.com/130693.html|title=بعد استقالة الميلياردير الشعبي من البرلمان..نجله محسن يلتحق بحزب مزوار - فبراير.كوم {{!}} موقع مغربي إخباري شامل يتجدد على مدار الساعة|date=2014-12-30|work=فبراير.كوم {{!}} موقع مغربي إخباري شامل يتجدد على مدار الساعة|access-date=2017-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref> while his late son Mohamed and his other son Faouzi, held the same positions in the past.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chambredesrepresentants.ma/ar/186-2|title=فوزي الشعبي|date=2014-10-10|work=مجلس النواب، البرلمان، المملكة المغربية|access-date=2017-09-12|language=ar}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bladi.net/mort-mohamed-chaabi.html|title=Mort de Mohamed Chaâbi, fils du milliardaire marocain Miloud Chaâbi|work=Bladi.net|access-date=2017-09-12|language=fr}}</ref> He was also the parliamentary representative of Essaouira after winning the elections in 2011, until he resigned on December 8, 2014 due to his declining health.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parlement.ma/fe/_groupsp1.php?filename=20111230140524140|title=Chambre des représentants|website=Chambre des représentants|language=fr|access-date=2017-09-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ar.yabiladi.com/articles/details/31637/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%B1-%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%84%D9%88%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%B9%D8%A8%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D8%B3%D8%AA%D9%82%D9%8A%D9%84-%D9%85%D9%86.html|title=الملياردير ميلود الشعبي يستقيل من مجلس النواب|last=Yabiladi.com|access-date=2017-09-12|language=ar}}</ref> His seat in the parliament was taken by his daughter Asma, who was second on the electoral list.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://essaouiranews.com/2014/12/08/%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%84%D9%88%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%B9%D8%A8%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D8%B3%D8%AA%D9%82%D9%8A%D9%84-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%BA%D8%B1/|title=Welcome essaouiranews.com - Justhost.com|last=host|first=just|website=essaouiranews.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.alousboue.com/14957/14957/|title=أسماء الشعبي برلمانية جديدة في مجلس النواب|work=الأسبوع الصحفي|access-date=2017-09-12|language=ar}}</ref>
In 2011, his fortune was estimated by [[Forbes]] Magazine at some $3 billion which made him the sixth richest man in Africa at the time, and the wealthiest person in Morocco.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2011/89/africa-billionaires-11_Miloud-Chaabi_MZSZ.html|title=#6 Miloud Chaabi - Forbes.com|website=www.forbes.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-12}}</ref>
Chaâbi was also known for his philanthropic and charity work and donated 10% of his fortune to build the first American university in Morocco in conjunction with the [[University of Maryland, College Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bridgizz.com/en/blog/moroccan-miloud-chaabi-donates-portion-his-wealth-education|title=Moroccan Miloud Chaabi donates portion his wealth to education|publisher=Bridgizz.com|accessdate=March 8, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090404150234/http://www.bridgizz.com/en/blog/moroccan-miloud-chaabi-donates-portion-his-wealth-education|archivedate=April 4, 2009|df=}}</ref> He was the operator of one of the largest charity organisations in Morocco, the Miloud Chaâbi Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fondationmiloudchaabi.com/|title=La Fondation Miloud Chaabi|publisher=The Miloud Chaâbi Foundation|accessdate=March 8, 2009}}</ref>
==Biography== As a child he was taught in a mosque and started working alternatively as a goat herder and farmer. At 15, he saved up enough money and moved from [[Marrakech]] to [[Kenitra]] where he started his first construction company in 1948.
At a time when trading business in Kenitra was restricted to the French, some Jewish businessmen, and some of the well known Moroccan families, Chaâbi ventured into the field. His interest went toward the ceramic industry which made him start his own ceramic company in 1964. Soon, Chaâbi gained enough experience in the business and began to seek for opportunities to purchase large companies. He offered to become an investor in a French company but the company refused his offer, which drove him to keep pressuring it by selling products with competitive prices until it had finally collapsed and was on the verge of bankruptcy. In 1985, the company sold all of its properties to Chaâbi himself. This success was a turning point for Chaâbi's professional career, and as a result he founded [[Ynna Group]] which became one of the most powerful holding companies in Morocco.
In 1992, he founded JBC for [[cardboard]] paper and got a deal for the sale of the petrochemical company [[Société nationale d'électrolyse et de pétrochimie|SNEP]] in 1993. In 1994, he launched ELECTRA for electrical components, cables and television batteries. In 1998, he launched Aswak Assalam shopping chain which was followed by the launch of Riyad Mogador hotel chain in 1999.
==Political career== Until he resigned in 2014, Miloud Chaabi won all Moroccan parliamentary elections since 1984,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chambredesrepresentants.ma/ar/anciens-deputes/%D8%AA%D8%B9%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%84-%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%84%D9%88%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%B9%D8%A8%D9%8A-anciens-d%C3%A9put%C3%A9s|title=ميلود الشعبي|date=2014-10-10|work=مجلس النواب، البرلمان، المملكة المغربية|access-date=2017-09-12|language=ar}}</ref> though he changed his political party multiple times. Parties of which he was a member include [[Party of Progress and Socialism]] and [[Environment and Development Party]]. In July 2008, he heavily criticized Driss Jettou's government for selling public properties at low prices without taking the proper legal procedures.
==See also== *[[Othman Benjelloun]] *[[Anas Sefrioui]] *[[Aziz Akhannouch]]
==References== {{Reflist}} <ref>http://www.parlement.ma/fe/_groupsp1.php?filename=20111230140524140</ref>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chaabi, Miloud}}

revision.comment: redundancy
revision.text:
'''Mini-MBA''' is a [[training]] regimen focused on the fundamentals of [[business]]. Mini-MBA programs are typically non-credit bearing programs that require less than 100 hours of total learning.<ref>University of North Carolina [http://www.kenan-flagler.unc.edu/businessessentials/faq.htm#8 "About the UNC Business Essentials Business Certificate Program"]</ref> Mini-MBA will also be applicable to the other programs viz., Advanced Management Program (AMP), General Management Program (GMP) etc. that confer alumni status of the business school. Such mini-MBA programs are offered by several leading business schools, including Harvard Business School, [[McGill Executive Institute]] (McGill University)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://executive.mcgill.ca/mini-mba|title=Mini-MBA Series {{!}} McGill Executive Institute|website=executive.mcgill.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-02-13}}</ref>, Wharton, Columbia, Stanford, Booth Chicago, INSEAD, London Business School, [[Florida Institute of Technology]],<ref>Florida Institute of Technology [http://www.floridatechonline.com/graduate-certificate-mini-mba/ "Mini-MBA Certificate Programs]</ref> [[University at Buffalo]] and [[Rutgers University]]. In Denmark Mini MBA programs are offered by e.g.[[:da:IME|IME]] and [https://arosbusinessacademy.dk/kursus/mini-mba/ Aros Business Academy] and in Spain a [https://www.akademus.es/series-educacion/mini-mba-digital-power-management/ Mini MBA] program is offered by IEBS Business School and [[:es:Seedrocket|Seedrocket]].
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Business qualifications]] [http://bs.krok.edu.ua/ru/mini-mba/ Mini MBA in Ukraine]
{{education-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = | image = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Ekerö]], [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | residence = | nationality = [[Sweden|Swedish]] | alma_mater = | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Businessman]], [[Entrepreneur]], [[CEO]] of [[Escobar Inc]] and Co-Founder of dietbitcoin<ref>{{cite web |last = |first = |title = dietbitcoin |url = https://dietbitcoin.org/about-us.php |work = |date = |accessdate = March 16, 2018 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = |archivedate = |df = dmy-all }}</ref> | years_active = 2006–present | salary = | networth = | spouse = | website = | parents = | footnotes = | children = }} '''Olof K. Gustafsson''' (born 14 May 1993)<ref>{{cite web|title=Olof K. Gustafsson - Google Knowledge graph|url=https://g.co/kgs/uHYmX5|accessdate=17 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[entrepreneur]]<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | date = October 24, 2010 | title = Olof Gustafsson - 17 | trans-title = | url = | language = Swedish | newspaper = [[Aftonbladet]] | location = | access-date = }}</ref> and [[businessman]],<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | date = January 5, 2011 | title = Olof Gustafsson's gymnasiestudier | trans-title = | url = | language = Swedish | newspaper = [[Aftonbladet]] | location = | access-date = }}</ref> currently serving as [[CEO]] of [[Escobar Inc]], a holding company for [[Pablo Escobar|Pablo]] and [[Roberto de Jesús Escobar Gaviria|Roberto Escobar Gaviria]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.newsweek.com/narcos-pablo-escobars-brother-wants-1-billion-netflix-slams-actor-wagner-moura-478451 | title='Narcos': Pablo Escobar's brother wants $1 billion from Netflix, slams actor Wagner Moura | author=Tufayel Ahmed | work= [[Newsweek]] | date=July 7, 2016 | accessdate=January 2, 2017}}</ref>
==Career== At age 13 he founded his first company retailing [[comics]] online in [[Sweden]].<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | date = October 11, 2010 | title = 17 år och fem företag: Jag ska bli miljardär | trans-title = | url = http://www.dagensps.se/artiklar/2010/11/10/72817209/index.xml | language = Swedish | newspaper = Dagens PS | location = | access-date = June 9, 2016 }}</ref> At age ==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gustafsson, Olof}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:1993 births]]

{{multiple issues| {{Globalize/US|date=May 2009}} {{POV|date=April 2014}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:Waitress taking an order.jpg|thumb|325px|A [[waitress]] writes down the food order of diners]]
In the [[United States]] and (at least some) other English-speaking countries, a '''pink-collar- worker''' refers to someone working in the care-oriented career field or in jobs historically considered to be "women’s work." This may include jobs in nursing, teaching, secretarial work, waitressing, or child care.<ref name="statistic1"/> While these jobs may be filled by men, they are typically female-dominated and may or may not pay significantly less than [[White-collar worker|white-collar]] or [[Blue-collar worker|blue-collar]] jobs.<ref name="statistic2"/>
==Etymology== The term "pink-collar" was popularized in the late 1970s by writer and social critic Louise Kapp Howe to denote women working as nurses, secretaries, and elementary school teachers. Its origins, however, go back to the early 1970s, to when the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) was placed before the states for ratification. At that time, the term was used to denote secretarial staff as well as non-professional office staff, all of which were largely held by women. These positions were not white-collar jobs, but neither were they blue-collar, manual labor. Hence, the creation of the term "pink-collar," which indicated it was not white-collar, was nonetheless an office job and one that was overwhelmingly filled by women.
== Occupations == Pink-collar occupations tend to be personal-service-oriented worker working in retail, nursing, and [[Teacher|teaching]] (depending on the level), are part of the [[service sector]], and are among the most common occupations in the [[United States]]. The [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] estimates that, as of May 2008, there were over 2.2 million persons employed as servers in the United States.<ref name="statistic1">{{cite web |url=http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes353031.htm |title=Occupational Employment and Wages - Waiters and Waitresses |accessdate=2006-12-31 |author=U.S. Department of Labor - Bureau of Labor Statistics |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=24 May 2006 |work= |publisher=US Department of Labor }}</ref> Furthermore, the [[World Health Organization]]'s 2011 World Health Statistics Report states that there are 19.3 million nurses in the world today.<ref name="statistic2">{{cite web|title=World Health Statistics 2011|url=http://www.who.int/whosis/whostat/2011/en/|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref> In the United States, women comprise 92.1% of the registered nurses that are currently employed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Quick Facts on Registered Nurses|url=http://www.dol.gov/wb/factsheets/Qf-nursing.htm|publisher=US Department of Labor|accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
Pink-collar occupations include:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://money.usnews.com/money/careers/articles/2012/09/10/the-pink-collar-job-boom | title=The Pink-Collar Job Boom | publisher=US News | accessdate=13 June 2014 | author=David Francis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://nbclatino.com/2012/06/27/nine-pink-collar-jobs-men-want-most/ | title=Nine pink collar jobs men want most | publisher=NBC | date=2012-06-27 | accessdate=29 June 2014 | author=Katerina Sardi}}</ref> {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Car attendant]] / [[Washroom attendant]] * [[Parking enforcement officer|Meter Maid]] / Parking lot attendant
===Architecture=== * [[Interior designer]] * [[Landscape designer]]
=== Education === * [[Librarian]] / [[Teacher-librarian]] * [[Library assistant]] / [[Library technician]] * [[Preschool teacher]] / Early childhood educator / Kindergarten teacher * Special education teacher * [[Teaching assistant]]
=== Healthcare === * [[Nurse]] / [[Registered nurse]] / [[Wet nurse]] * [[Dental assistant]] / [[Medical assistant]] / Pharmacy assistant * [[Dental hygienist]] * [[Psychiatric rehabilitation|Rehabilitation specialist]] * [[Nutritionist]] / [[Dietitian]] * Hospital attendant / Hospital service worker / Nurse's aide
=== Administration === * Advertising and promotions managers * [[Bank teller]] * [[Bookkeeper]] * Marketing coordinator / Marketing assistant * [[Human resources]] manager * [[Legal secretary]] * [[Paralegal]] * [[Public relations]] manager * [[Receptionist]] / [[Secretary]] / [[Administrative Assistant]] / Information clerk
===Entertainment=== * [[Actor]] * [[Production manager]]
