=== Sport === * [[Cheerleader]] * [[Dancer]] / [[Choreographer]] / [[Dance instructor]] * [[Fitness instructor]] }}
== Background == Historically, women were responsible for the running of a household.<ref>Ware 1982, p. 17</ref> Their financial security was often dependent upon a male patriarch. Widowed or divorced women struggled to support themselves and their children.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 333</ref>
Women began to develop more opportunities when they moved into the paid workplace, formerly of the male domain. In the 20th century women aimed to be treated like the equals of their male counterparts. In 1920 American women won the [[suffrage|right to vote]], marking a turning point in their roles in life.<ref>Naffziger, Claudeen Cline; et al. (1974). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/582762 "Development of Sex Role Stereotypes"], ''The Family Coordinator'' '''256''' (3)</ref>
Many single women traveled to cities like New York where they found work in factories and [[sweatshop]]s, working for low pay operating sewing machines, sorting feathers, rolling tobacco and so on.<ref>Gourley 2008, p. 103</ref>
These factories were dirty, noisy, dark, and dangerous. Workers frequently breathed dangerous fumes and worked with flammable materials.<ref name="humowitz239">Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 239</ref> Women lost fingers and hands in accidents because in order to save money they were required to clean and adjust the machines while they were running.<ref name="humowitz239"/> Unfortunately, most women who worked in the factories did not earn enough money to live on and lived in poverty.
Throughout the 20th century certain women helped change women's roles in America. [[Emily Balch]], [[Jane Addams]], and [[Lillian Wald]] are among the most notable.<ref name="gourley99">Gourley 2008, p. 99.</ref> They created settlement houses and launched missions in crowded, unsanitary neighborhoods where immigrants lived.<ref name="gourley99"/> Balch, Addams, and Wald offered social services to the women and children, often inviting them into their homes and classrooms.<ref name="gourley99"/>
Women took on leadership roles starting in the church. Women became involved with the church activities, a few went on to become president of the societies. The women who joined these societies worked with their members some of whom were full-time teachers, nurses, missionaries, and social workers to accomplish their leadership tasks and make a difference.<ref name="Wallace">Wallace, Ruth A (2000). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1388082 "Women and Religion: The Transformation of Leadership Roles,"] ''Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion'' '''502''' (4)</ref> The [[Association for the Sociology of Religion]] was the first to elect a woman president in 1938.<ref name="Wallace"/>
=== During World Wars I and II === [[File:U.S. Navy Nurse Corps recruiting poster, January 1945 (NH 78855).jpg|150px|thumb|left|A [[U.S. Navy]] recruiting poster from World War II, showing an officer of the [[Navy WAVES]] before a hospital ship]]
[[World War I]] was the beginning of "pink-collar jobs" as the military needed personnel to type letters, answer phones, and perform other tasks. One thousand women worked for the U.S. Navy as [[stenographer]]<nowiki/>s, clerks, and telephone operators.<ref>Gourley 2008, p. 119</ref>
The field of nursing also became [[Feminisation of the workplace|"feminized"]] and was an accepted profession for women. In 1917, [[Louisa Lee Schuyler]] opened the [[Bellevue Hospital School of Nursing]], the first to train women as professional nurses.<ref>Gourley 2008, p. 123</ref> After completing training, some female nurses worked in hospitals, but most worked in field tents.
[[World War II]] marked the first time women began working in high-paying industrial jobs. They worked in factories and some even joined the armed forces. These women were segregated from men in separate groups. Although women joined the workforce they still encountered discrimination in and out of the workplace, which persisted despite [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|anti-discrimination laws passed in the 1960s]].<ref name="Emily Stoper 1991"/>
Women who joined the armed forces participated in every military field except combat. One thousand female pilots joined the [[Women Airforce Service Pilots]], one hundred and forty thousand women joined the [[Women's Army Corps]] and one hundred thousand women joined the [[U.S. Navy]] as nurses and administrative staff.<ref>{{cite book |last=May |first=Elaine Tyler |title=Pushing the Limits |publisher=Oxford University |location=New York |year=1994 |page=41}}</ref>
Two million women held office jobs during World War II, which offered job security because they had become "feminized".<ref>{{cite book |last=Hartmann |first=Susan M. |title=The Home Front and Beyond |publisher=G.K. Hall & Co. |location=Boston |year=1982 |page=88}}</ref>
== Life in the working world == [[File:Pink 2.JPG|thumb|This graph shows the increase in women graduating high school and attending college, while there is a decrease in high school dropouts.]]
A typical job sought by working women was that of a [[switchboard operator|telephone operator]] or [[Hello Girls|Hello Girl]]. The Hello Girls began as women who operated on switchboards during the first world war by answering telephones and talking to impatient callers in a calming tone.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/rr/news/topics/hello.html|title=Topics in Chronicling America-Hello Girls|last=|first=|date=January 29, 2015|website=The Library of Congress|access-date=December 8, 2017}}</ref> The workers would sit on stools facing a wall with hundreds of outlets and tiny blinking lights. The women had to work quickly when a light flashed by plugging the cord into the proper outlet. Despite the difficult work, many women wanted this job because it paid five dollars a week and provided a rest lounge for the employees to take a break.<ref name="Catherine Gourley 2008"/>
Female secretaries were also popular. They were instructed to be efficient, tough, and hardworking while also appearing soft, accommodating, and subservient.<ref name="jstor.org">Rung, Margaret C. (1997). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3116078 "Paternalism and Pink Collar: Gender and Federal Employee Relations,1941-50,"] ''The Business History Review'' '''399''' (3)</ref> Women were expected to be the protector and partner to their boss behind closed doors and a helpmate in public. These women were encouraged to go to charm schools and express their personality through fashion instead of furthering their education.<ref name="jstor.org"/>
[[Social work]] became a female-dominated profession in the 1930s, emphasizing a group professional identity and the casework method.<ref name="Susan Ware 1982">Ware 1982, p. 74</ref> Social workers gave crucial expertise for the expansion of federal, state and local government, as well as services to meet the needs of the Depression.<ref name="Susan Ware 1982"/>
Teachers in primary and secondary schools remained female, although as the war progressed, women began to move on to better employment and higher salaries.<ref name="ReferenceA">Ware 1982, p. 102</ref> In 1940, teaching positions paid less than $1,500 a year and fell to $800 in rural areas.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Women scientists found it hard to gain appointments at universities. Women scientists were forced to take positions in high schools, state or women's colleges, governmental agencies and alternative institutions such as libraries or museums.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Women who took jobs at such places often did clerical duties and though some held professional positions, these boundaries were blurred.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Mostly women were hired as librarians who had been professionalized and feminized. In 1920, women accounted for 88% of librarians in the United States.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Two-thirds of the [[American Geographical Society]] (AGS)'s employees were women, who served as librarians, editorial personnel in the publishing programs, secretaries, research editors, copy editors, proofreaders, research assistants and sales staff. These women came with credentials from well-known colleges and universities and many were overqualified for their positions, but later were promoted to more prestigious positions.
Although female employees did not receive equal pay, they did get sabbaticals to attend university and to travel for their professions at the cost of the AGS.<ref name="ReferenceB">Monk, Janice (April 2003). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/30033908 "Women's Worlds at the American Geographical Society,"] ''Geographical Review'' '''93''' (2): 237–257</ref> Those women working managerial and library or museums positions made an impact on women in the work force, but still encountered discrimination when they tried to advance.
In the 1940s, clerical work expanded to occupy the largest number of women employees, this field diversified as it moved into commercial service.<ref>Susan M. Hartmann, The Home Front and Beyond (Boston, MA: G.K. Hall &Co., 1982), p. 94.</ref> The average worker in the 1940s was over 35 years old, married, and needed to work to keep their families afloat.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 314</ref>
During the 1950s, women were taught that marriage and domesticity were more important than a career. Most women followed this path because of the uncertainty of the post-war years.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 326</ref> Suburban housewives were encouraged to have hobbies like bread making and sewing. The 1950s housewife was in conflict between being "just a housewife" because their upbringing taught them competition and achievement. Many women had furthered their education deriving a sense of self-worth.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 332</ref>
=== Pay ===
A single woman working in a factory in the early 20th century earned less than $8 a week, which is equivalent to roughly less that $98 dollars a week today.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.usinflationcalculator.com/|title=US Inflation Calculator|website=US Inflation Calculator|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> If the woman was absent or was late, employers penalized them by docking their pay.<ref name="Catherine Gourley 2008">Gourley 2008, p. 105</ref> These women would live in boarding houses costing $1.50 a week, waking at 5:30 a.m. to start their ten-hour work day. When women entered the paid workforce in the 1920s they were paid less than men because employers thought the women's jobs were temporary. Employers also paid women less than men because they believed in the "Pin Money Theory", which said that women's earnings were secondary to that of their male counterparts. With this being said, women took typical jobs that were "considerably less substantial than their husbands' in terms of both the average number of hours worked per week as well as continuity over time".<ref name="Hilary Silver 1993">Silver, Hilary. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/684634 "Housework and Domestic Work,"] ''Sociological Forum'' 182 no.2 (1993).</ref> However, working women still experienced stress and overload because they were still responsible for the majority of the housework and taking care of the children. This left women isolated and subjected them to their husband's control.<ref name="Hilary Silver 1993" />
In the early 1900s women's pay was one to three dollars a week and much of that went to living expenses.<ref>Archer, Jules (1991). ''Breaking Barriers'' (New York: The Penguin Group), p. 27.</ref> In the 1900s female tobacco strippers earned five dollars a week, half of what their male coworkers made and [[seamstress]]es made six to seven dollars a week compared to a cutter's salary of $16.<ref name="ReferenceC">Woloch 1984, p. 27</ref> This differed from women working in factories in the 1900s as they were paid by the piece, not receiving a fixed weekly wage.<ref name="humowitz236-7">Humowitz Weissman 1978, pp. 236–237</ref> Those that were pinching pennies pushed themselves to produce more product so that they earned more money.<ref name="humowitz236-7" /> Women who earned enough to live on found it impossible to keep their salary rate from being reduced because bosses often made "mistakes" in computing a worker's piece rate.<ref name="Humowitz240">Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 240</ref> As well as this, women who received this kind of treatment did not disagree for fear of losing their jobs. Employers would frequently deduct pay for work they deemed imperfect and for simply trying to lighten the mood by laughing or talking while they worked.<ref name="Humowitz240" /> In the 1937 a woman's average yearly salary was $525 compared to a man's salary of $1,027.<ref name="ReferenceC" /> In the 1940s two-thirds of the women who were in the labor force suffered a decrease in earnings; the average weekly paychecks fell from $50 to $37.<ref name="Emily Stoper 1991" /> This gap in wage stayed consistent, as women in 1991 only earned seventy percent of what men earned regardless of their education.<ref name="Emily Stoper 1991">Stoper, Emily (May 1991). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1046935 "Women's Work, Women's Movement: Taking Stock,"] ''Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science'' '''515''' pp. 151–152</ref>
Later on in the 1970s and 1980s as women began to fight for equality, they fought against discrimination in jobs where women worked and the educational institutions that would lead to those jobs.<ref name="Emily Stoper 1991" /> In 1973 the average salaries for women were 57% compared to those of men, but this [[gender pay gap|gender earnings gap]] was especially noticeable in pink-collar jobs where the largest number of women were employed.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 364</ref> Women were given routine, less responsible jobs available and often with a lower pay than men. These jobs were monotonous and mechanical often with assembly-line procedures.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 304</ref>
In 1975, a study was carried out that examined the pay differences between single and married women. It was found that married women made substantially less than single women, as single women made up to 97% of what a single man would make and married women would only make up to 62% of married men's pay.<ref name="Waldfogel 1995 584–610">{{Cite journal|last=Waldfogel|first=Jane|date=1995|title=The Price of Motherhood: Family Status and Women's Pay in Young British Cohort|jstor=2663545|journal=Oxford Economic Papers|volume=47|issue=4|pages=584–610}}</ref> This was found to potentially be because of taking maternity leaves, as less work related experience would be gained in the time that these women left to care for their children, leading to less investment from the company.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Waldfogel|first=Jane|date=1997|title=The Effect of Children on Women's Wages|jstor=2657300|journal=American Sociological Review|volume=62|issue=2|pages=209–217|doi=10.2307/2657300}}</ref> It was also found that women now are more likely to join or re-join the work force after having children, rather than the traditional role of becoming a stay at home mother.<ref name="Waldfogel 1995 584–610"/>
=== Education ===
Women entering the workforce had difficulty finding a satisfactory job without references or an education.<ref>Gourley 2008, p. 104</ref> However, opportunities for [[higher education]] expanded as women were admitted to all-male schools like the [[United States service academies]] and [[Ivy League]] strongholds.<ref>Woloch 1984, p. 525</ref> Education became a way for society to shape women into its ideal housewife. In the 1950s, authorities and educators encouraged college because they found new value in vocational training for domesticity.<ref>Woloch 1984, p. 500</ref> College prepared women for future roles because while men and women were taught together, they were groomed for different paths after they graduated.<ref>Woloch 1984, p. 405</ref> Education started out as a way to teach women how to be a good wife, but education also allowed women to broaden their minds.
Being educated was an expectation for women entering the paying workforce, despite the fact that their male equivalents did not need a high school diploma.<ref>Humowitz Weissman 1978, p. 316</ref> While in college, a woman would experience extracurricular activities, such as a sorority, that offered a separate space for the woman to practice types of social service work that was expected from her.<ref name="Nancy Woloch 1984">Woloch 1984, p. 404</ref>
However, not all of a woman's education was done in the classroom. Women were also educated through their peers through "dating". Men and women no longer had to be supervised when alone together. Dating allowed men and women to practice the paired activities that would later become a way of life.<ref name="Nancy Woloch 1984"/>
New women's organizations sprouted up working to reform and protect women in the workplace. The largest and most prestigious of these organizations was The General Federation of Women's Clubs (GFWC), whose members were conservative middle-class housewives. The International Ladies Garment Workers Union (ILGWU) was formed after women shirtwaist makers went on strike in New York City in 1909. It started as a small walkout, with a handful of members from one shop and grew to a force of ten of thousands, changing the course of the labor movement forever. In 1910 women allied themselves with the Progressive Party who sought to reform social issues.
Another organization that grew out of women in the workforce, was the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor. The Women's Bureau regulated conditions for women employees. As female labor became a crucial part of the economy, efforts by the Women's Bureau increased. The Bureau pushed for employers to take advantage of "women-power" and persuaded women to enter the employment market.
In 1913 the ILGWU signed the well-known "protocol in the Dress and Waist Industry" which was the first contract between labor and management settled by outside negotiators. The contract formalized the trade's division of labor by gender.
Another win for women came in 1921 when congress passed the Sheppard-Towner Act, a welfare measure intended to reduce infant and maternal mortality; it was the first federally funded healthcare act. The act provided federal funds to establish health centers for prenatal and child care. Expectant mothers and children could receive health checkups and health advice. <!-- This paragraph seems to be more about the expansions of women's rights than it is about pink-collar workers, I would recommend taking it out Kali Moumblow (talk) 20:11, 16 November 2017 (UTC)) -->
In 1963 the Equal Pay Act was passed making it the first federal law against sex discrimination, equal pay for equal work, and made employers hire women workers if they qualified from the start.
Unions also became a major outlet for women to fight against the unfair treatment they experienced. Women who joined these types of unions stayed before and after work to talk about the benefits of the union, collect dues, obtain charters, and form bargaining committees.
The National Recovery Administration (NRA) was approved in May 1933. The NRA negotiated codes designed to rekindle production. It raised wages, shortened workers' hours, and increased employment for the first time maximizing hour and minimizing wage provisions benefiting female workers. The NRA had its flaws however, it only covered half of the women in the workforce particularly manufacturing and trade. The NRA regulated working conditions only for women with a job and did not offer any relief for the two million unemployed women who desperately needed it.
The 1930s proved successful for women in the workplace thanks to federal relief programs and the growth of unions. For the first time women were not completely dependent on themselves, in 1933 the federal government expanded in its responsibility to female workers. In 1938 the Fair Labor Standards Act grew out of several successful strikes. Two million women joined the workforce during the Great Depression despite negative public opinion.
==Pink ghetto== "'''Pink ghetto'''" is a term used to refer to jobs dominated by women. The term was coined in 1983 to describe the limits women have in furthering their careers, since the jobs are often dead-end, stressful and underpaid. The term ''pink ghetto'' is just simply another way of describing pink-collar work. ''Pink ghetto'' was more commonly used in the early years, when women were finally able to work. Pink-collar work became the popular term once it was popularized by Louise Kapp Howe, a writer and social critic, in the 1970s.
''Pink ghetto'' can also describe the placement of female managers into positions that will not lead them to the [[board room]], thus perpetuating the "[[glass ceiling]]". This includes managing areas such as human resources, customer service, and other areas that do not contribute to the corporate "bottom line". While this allows women to rise in ranks as a manager, their career eventually stalls out and they're excluded from the upper echelons.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2002727003_kleiman08.html |title=Pink-collar workers fight to leave "ghetto" |first=Carol |last=Kleiman |work=[[Seattle Times]] |date=8 January 2006 |accessdate=2008-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://thenewagenda.net/2009/02/10/promises-unkept-in-the-enduring-pink-ghetto |title=Promises Unkept in the Enduring Pink Ghetto |first=Gretchen |last=Glasscock |work=The New Agenda |date=2009-02-10 |accessdate= 2010-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.womenssportsfoundation.org/Content/Articles/Issues/Equity-Issues/P/Posting-Up-in-the-Pink-Ghetto.aspx |title=Posting Up in the Pink Ghetto |first=Sarah |last=Murray |work=[[Women's Sports Foundation]] |date=2008-01-08 |accessdate=2010-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616054423/http://womenssportsfoundation.org/Content/Articles/Issues/Equity-Issues/P/Posting-Up-in-the-Pink-Ghetto.aspx |archivedate=16 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Male integration == Scholars such as Judy Wajcman argue that technology has long been monopolized by men and is a great source of their power historically.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=BtaiFSv09jMC&oi=fnd&pg=PR6&dq=technology+displaces+jobs+for+men&ots=KDnJauxEJQ&sig=OWtNUf_MqgUz-VTNZPDigVtTJEY#v=onepage&q=technology%20displaces%20jobs%20for%20men&f=false|title=Feminism Confronts Technology|last=Wajcman|first=Judy|date=1991|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=0271008024|language=en}}</ref> However, more millennial men are doing pink collar work because technology is affecting blue collar work. Machines are able to perform many of the tasks that were typically gendered male within factories. In a 1990 study conducted by Allan H. Hunt and Timothy L. Hunt, they examined how industrial robots would impact both the creation of jobs as well as job displacement among unskilled workers in the United States. It was concluded that the impact of unemployment due to the spread of robotics would be felt the greatest by uneducated, unskilled blue-collar workers. New technology in the form of robotics eliminates many semi or unskilled jobs, and has taken traditional men filled roles away from the job market.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=L.|first=Hunt, H. Allan{{!}}Hunt, Timothy|date=1983-00-00|title=Human Resource Implications of Robotics.|url=https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED228547|language=en}}</ref> Judy Wajman maintains that skills involving machines and strength are associated with masculinity.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Male Designs on Technology|last=Wajman|first=Judy|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=27}}</ref> This means that the least technical jobs (pink-collar) jobs are associated with women. These machines designed by men, using the technology they have always monopolized, are now displacing them and forcing them into feminized pink-collar work.
It was found as well that men going into traditionally claimed pink collar jobs are felt discriminated and threatened in their jobs.<ref name="Kalokerinos 553–565">{{Cite journal|last=Kalokerinos|first=Elise K.|last2=Kjelsaas|first2=Kathleen|last3=Bennetts|first3=Steven|last4=von Hippel|first4=Courtney|date=2017-08-01|title=Men in pink collars: Stereotype threat and disengagement among male teachers and child protection workers|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ejsp.2246/abstract|journal=European Journal of Social Psychology|language=en|volume=47|issue=5|pages=553–565|doi=10.1002/ejsp.2246|issn=1099-0992}}</ref> Men going into positions such as teaching, nursing and childcare faced many negative stereotypes in these lines of work, as men have traditionally been viewed as stern, strong and holding dominant attitudes. This stereotype about men negatively impacts men in these lines of work, as it is expected that a woman with the same position would be more nurturing, caring and well suited for the work.<ref name="Kalokerinos 553–565"/>
== See also == * [[Blue-collar worker]] * [[Designation of workers by collar color]] * [[Office lady]] * [[White-collar worker]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== *Gourley, Catherine (2008). ''Gibson Girls and Suffragists: Perceptions of Women from 1900 to 1918'' (Minneapolis, MN: Twenty-First Century Books) {{ISBN|978-0-8225-7150-6}} *Humowitz, Carol; Weissman, Michelle (1978). ''A History of Women in America'' (New York: Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith) {{ISBN|0-553-20762-8}} *{{cite book |title=Holding Their Own |last=Ware |first=Susan |year=1982 |publisher=G.K. Hall & Co |location=Boston |isbn=0-8057-9900-1}} *{{cite book |title=Women and the American Experience |last=Woloch |first=Nancy |year=1984 |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location= New York |isbn=0-394-53515-4}}
==External links== {{wiktionary|pink-collar}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050505194045/http://bartleby.com/61/52/P0315200.html The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition] *[http://www.worlddata.com/datacard/viewdatacard.asp?ID=2609{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Workers in the Pink Collar Market Place] *[https://www.census.gov/Press-Release/cb98-181.htm{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Census Bureau, Measuring 50 Years of Economic Change] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090209072059/http://www.womenwork.org/policy/factwomenwork.htm Women Work! Women in the Workforce] *[http://www.depts.drew.edu/wmst/studentRes/statistics.htm Statistics on Women] *[http://www.9to5.org 9to5, National Association of Working Women]

{{Infobox person | name = Reza Zarrab | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Reza Zarrab | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1983|9|12}} | birth_place = [[Tabriz]], [[Iran]] | citizenship = [[Iran]]{{cite news|title=Turkish National Arrested for Conspiring to Evade U.S. Sanctions Against Iran, Money Laundering and Bank Fraud|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/turkish-national-arrested-conspiring-evade-us-sanctions-against-iran-money-laundering-and|access-date=22 March 2016|work=US Department of Justice|date=21 March 2016}}
[[Azerbaijan]]
[[Turkey]]{{cite news ||first=Humeyra |last=Pamuk| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/29/us-iran-turkey-special-report-idUSBREA3S07120140429| title=Special Report – Golden Loophole: How an alleged Turkish crime ring helped Iran| date=29 April 2014|agency=[[Reuters]]|access-date=29 April 2014}}
[[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] | residence = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | alma_mater = | years_active = 2004–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Ebru Gündeş]]|2010}} | children = 1 | website = | footnotes = | signature = }} '''Reza Zarrab''' ({{lang-fa|رضا ضراب}}, {{lang-tr|Rıza Sarraf}};{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/904978-29-yasindaki-reza-zarrabin-hikayesi |title=Yolsuzluk operasyonu, Reza Zarrab kimdir|work=Haberturk.com |date=19 December 2013|access-date=23 March 2014}} born 12 September 1983 in [[Tabriz]], [[Iran]]) is a Turkey-based businessman. He has quadruple [[Iran]]ian, [[Azerbaijan]]i, [[Turkey|Turkish]] and [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonian]] citizenship.{{cite news |title=Turkey corruption allegations included in Reza Zarrab case in US |author= |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkey-corruption-allegations-included-in-reza-zarrab-case-in-us.aspx?PageID=238&NID=99684&NewsCatID=509 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=26 May 2016 |access-date=28 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.turkishminute.com/2016/06/16/ny-court-denies-bail-iranian-mogul-zarrab-announces-us-attorney-bharara/|title=NY court denies bail for Iranian mogul Zarrab, announces US Attorney Bharara – Turkish Minute|first=|last=TM|website=www.TurkisMminute.com|access-date=3 November 2017}} On 19 March 2016 he was arrested in the [[United States]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/turkish-national-arrested-conspiring-evade-us-sanctions-against-iran-money-laundering-and|title=Turkish National Arrested for Conspiring to Evade U.S. Sanctions Against Iran, Money Laundering and Bank Fraud|website=www.justice.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-30}} and is accused of being a member of international criminal organization. He was charged with evading the US [[economic sanctions]] on Iran and [[money laundering]] in an alleged [[racket (crime)|racket]] scheme to help Iran bypass the sanctions, involving ministers of the Turkish government of then prime minister and now president of Turkey, [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]].{{cite news|title=Is corruption suspect's US arrest bad news for Erdogan?|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/03/turkey-iran-usa-arrest-of-zarrab-bad-news-for-erdogan.html|work=Al-Monitor|date=23 March 2016|accessdate=2016-11-06}}{{cite news|title=Iran’s Turkish connection: Golden squeal: Did officials help evade sanctions?|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21700422-did-officials-help-evade-sanctions-golden-squeal|work=[[The Economist]]|date=11 June 2016|accessdate=2016-11-06}} His father, Hossein Zarrab, had a close relationship with [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]],{{cite web|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/05/iran-babak-zanjani-reza-zarrab-corruption-cases.html|title=The downfall of two Iranian tycoons|first=|last=mshabani|date=9 May 2016|website=al-monitor.com|accessdate=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020191142/https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/05/iran-babak-zanjani-reza-zarrab-corruption-cases.html#|archive-date=2017-10-20|dead-url=yes|df=}} who served as the [[President of Iran]] between 2005 and 2013. The U.S. Department of Treasury accused Hossein Zarrab of violating U.S. sanctions on Iran and slapped a $9.1 million fine against him. His fine reduced to $2.3 million following his colloboration with the U.S. officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/yazarlar/tolga-tanis/zarrabi-kim-tc-vatandasi-yapti-40113274|title=Zarrab’ı kim TC vatandaşı yaptı|website=hurriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Zarrab was arrested by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] in Miami in the US on March 19, 2016 and was accused of bank fraud, money laundering and helping the Iranian government in evading the US economic sanctions on Iran to hinder its nuclear-weapons program. His charges; conspiracy to defraud, violating the [[International Emergency Economic Powers Act]], money laundering, and bank fraud; could bring up to 70 years in prison if found guilty in the U.S. Federal Court.{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/turkish-national-arrested-conspiring-evade-us-sanctions-against-iran-money-laundering-and|title=Turkish National Arrested for Conspiring to Evade U.S. Sanctions Against Iran, Money Laundering and Bank Fraud|website=www.justice.gov|accessdate=3 November 2017}} ==Early life== Zarrab was born in Tabriz to [[Iranian Azerbaijani]] parents{{cite news | url=http://iranwire.com/fa/projects/4057 | title=حاشیه‌های بازداشت تاجر ایرانی در ترکیه؛ از بابک زنجانی تا مشایی | date=2013-12-18 | agency=Iran Wire | accessdate=2013-12-18}} and grew up in [[Azerbaijan]] and [[Turkey]]. Reza Zarrab became a dual citizen of [[Turkey]] and the [[Republic of Azerbaijan]] after settling in [[Istanbul]].{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2013/12/131218_l10_reza_zarrab_turkey.shtml | title=ایرانی بازداشت شده در ترکیه 'در مورد دور زدن تحریم‌ها بازجویی شده بود'| date=2013-12-18 | agency=[[BBC Persian]] | accessdate=2013-12-18}} Zarrab's parents remained in Baku through 2010–11; in 2013 they were granted Turkish citizenship reportedly through facilitation of then Interior Minister Muammer Güler. {{cite news|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/national_zarrabs-father-given-citizenship-via-exceptional-status_369768.html |title=Zarrab’s father given citizenship via ’exceptional status’ |date=2015-01-14 |agency=[[Zaman Daily News]] |accessdate=2016-03-22 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305082033/http://www.todayszaman.com/national_zarrabs-father-given-citizenship-via-exceptional-status_369768.html |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }} In 2008, Reza Zarrab married to a Turkish pop star, [[Ebru Gündeş]] and had a child in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.iha.com.tr/haber-reza-zarrab-kimdir-reza-zarrabin-hayati-ebru-gundesin-esi-reza-zarrab-317902/|title=Reza Zarrab kimdir? Reza Zarrab'ın hayatı. Ebru Gündeş'in eşi Reza Zarrab|website=iha.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} He started his business life in Turkey in 2008 with the company named Royal Maritime A.S. He founded Royal Holding with his brother Mohammed Zarrab (Can Sarraf) in 2010.http://royalholding.com.tr/index.php?royalholding=hakkimizda{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Zarrab’s chauffeur, Turgut Harpani, was arrested by the Turkish Customs Protection agency during his trip to Russia from Turkey in 2011 for carrying $150 millions in cash and was accused of conducting illegal money couriering, but he was then released by Turkish authorities.{{cite web|url=http://m.milliyet.com.tr/gundes-in-esinin-soforu-kacakciliktan-gozaltinda-magazin-1377987/|title=Gündeş’in eşinin şoförü kaçakçılıktan gözaltında – Magazin Haberleri|website=milliyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://m.haberturk.com/yasam/haber/620972-soforunde-150-milyon-dolar|title=Şoföründe 150 milyon dolar!|website=haberturk.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Happani shared his own pictures on Facebook with suitcases full of money. {{cite web|url=http://m.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/operasyonu_baslatan_fotograf_balya_balya_dolar-1166808/|title=Operasyonu başlatan fotoğraf: Facebook'ta balya balya dolar! – Türkiye Haberleri – Radikal|first=|last=Radikal|website=radikal.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} The Turkish National Intelligence Agency (MIT) urged then Prime Minister Erdoğan in April 2013 about Zarrab’s corrupted relations with the Turkish cabinet members.{{cite web|url=http://birgun.net/haber/mitten-erdogana-sarraf-raporu-12357.html|title=MİT'ten Erdoğan'a Sarraf raporu – BirGün.net – Halkın Gazetesi BirGün|date=19 March 2014|website=archive.org|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319222958/http://birgun.net/haber/mitten-erdogana-sarraf-raporu-12357.html|archivedate=19 March 2014|df=}} Zarrab received an “exceptional citizenship” and became a Turkish citizen with the decision given by the Turkish Council of Ministers on June 1, 2007. He was accused of bribing $1.5 million to receive Turkish Citizenship in the indictment.{{cite web|url=http://m.milliyet.com.tr/5-milyon-dolara-turk-vatandasi/gundem/detay/1809571/default.htm|title=5 milyon dolara Türk vatandaşı oldular – Son Dakika Haberler|website=milliyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} ==2013 corruption scandal in Turkey== {{main|2013 corruption scandal in Turkey}} Zarrab, who has a business affiliation with the Iranian billionaire and [[business magnate]] [[Babak Zanjani]], was detained in Istanbul on 17 December 2013 due to his involvement with the sons of three ministers ([[Erdoğan Bayraktar]], [[Muammer Güler]] and [[Zafer Çağlayan]]) in the [[Government of Turkey|Turkish government]] and [[Egemen Bağış]], the former minister for EU Affairs and Turkey's chief negotiator in accession talks with the [[European Union]],{{cite news | url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/uc_bakana_rusvet_suclamasi-1166735 | title=Üç bakana rüşvet suçlaması | date=2013-12-18 | agency=Radikal | accessdate=2013-12-18 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219021159/http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/uc_bakana_rusvet_suclamasi-1166735# | archive-date=2013-12-19 | dead-url=yes | df= }}{{cite news | url=http://t24.com.tr/haber/yolsuzluk-ve-rusvet-sorusturmasinda-egemen-bagis-goruntuleri-de-cikti/246398 | title=Yolsuzluk ve rüşvet soruşturmasında Egemen Bağış görüntüleri de çıktı! | date=2013-12-19 | agency=T24 | accessdate=2013-12-19}}{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/05/world/middleeast/to-this-tycoon-iran-sanctions-are-like-gold.html?_r=0| title=To This Tycoon, Iran Sanctions Were Like Gold| date=2013-10-05 | agency=New York Times | accessdate=2013-10-05}} in an alleged [[bribery]], [[corruption]] and [[smuggling]] racket.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/ekonomi/25378685.asp |title=İstanbul'da yolsuzluk ve rüşvet operasyonu |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-03-23}} The court ordered his arrest on 21 December along with Barış Güler, son of Muammer Güler, and Kaan Çağlayan, son of Zafer Çağlayan.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25412674.asp |title=2 Bakan oğlu ile Reza Zarrab tutuklandı |publisher=Hurriyet.com.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-03-23}} He was released on 28 February 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26387522 |title=Turkey frees cabinet ministers' sons |publisher=bbc.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-17}} The investigation in Turkey revealed a system to help Iran bypass US sanctions against the country concerning the [[Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication|SWIFT]] payment system, in a scheme based on Turkish public bank [[Halkbank]], whereby money was transferred to front companies in [[China]] and Turkey, and [[gold]] bought with that money transferred to Iran via [[Dubai]]. Then Interior Minister [[Muammer Güler]]’s son, Barış Güler, then Economy Minister [[Zafer Çağlayan|Zafer Çaglayan]]’s son, Kaan Çaglayan, and General Director of Halk Bank, Suleyman Arslan, were among the suspects including Reza Zarrab. They were arrested due to accusations of “bribery, professional misconduct, bid rigging, and smuggling”.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/amp/2-bakan-oglu-ile-reza-zarrab-tutuklandi-25412674|title=2 Bakan oğlu ile Reza Zarrab tutuklandı – Son Dakika Haberler|website=www.hurriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://m.hurriyet.com.tr/uc-bakanin-oglu-gozaltinda-25378920|title=Üç bakanın oğlu gözaltında|website=hurriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Erdogan backlashed and announced the investigation as a “judicial coup” against his government, and dismissed the prosecutors and police officials investigating the corruption scheme. After a 70-day detainment, Zarrab and the sons of cabinet members were released from jail.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/amp/reza-zarrab-ve-bakan-cocuklari-tahliye-edildi-25912625|title=Reza Zarrab ve Bakan çocukları tahliye edildi – Son Dakika Haberler|website=www.hurriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Erdogan received harsh criticism for obstructing and undermining justice and putting the judiciary under his executive authority. However, Erdogan announced that “justice has been served”.{{cite web|url=http://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/amp/haber/siyaset/46077/Erdogan__Adalet_yerini_buldu.html|title=Erdoğan: Adalet yerini buldu|website=cumhuriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Egemen Bağış, then Minister of European Union Affairs, was dismissed after the corruption investigation. The Ministers of Interior Affairs, Economic Relations, and Environment and Urbanization – Muammer Güler, Zafer Çaglayan, and Erdoğan Bayraktar, respectively – had to resign from their positions.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/turkce/haberler/2014/12/141212_17_25_aralik_operasyonu_neler_oldu_10_soruda|title=10 soruda: 17–25 Aralık operasyonları|first=Mahmut Hamsici BBC|last=Türkçe|website=BBC Türkçe|accessdate=3 November 2017}} The indictment charged high-ranked officials with significant accusations for receiving bribes: Zafer Caglayan received $52 million worth of bribes; Muammer Guler received $10 million worth of bribes; and Egemen Bağış received $1.5 million worth of bribes.{{cite web|url=http://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/amp/haber/turkiye/29997/Bagis__Caglayan_ve_Guler_kac_TL_rusvet_almakla_suclaniyor_.html|title=Bağış, Çağlayan ve Güler kaç TL rüşvet almakla suçlanıyor?|website=cumhuriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} The summary of proceedings were sent to the Turkish parliament for the vote on whether to lift ministers’ immunity and send them to court. However, given the strong majority of Erdoğan's ruling party (AKP), in January 2015 the parliament did not lift their immunity and swept away the significant investigation.{{cite web|url=http://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/amp/haber/turkiye/191219/AKP_li_vekiller_4_eski_bakan_icin_vicdanlarini_sifirladilar.html|title=AKP'li vekiller 4 eski bakan için vicdanlarını sıfırladılar|website=cumhuriyet.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} In May 2014, Erdoğan announced that he initiated a “witch-hunt” against the Gulen movement for, as he alleged, being behind the corruption investigation.{{cite web|url=http://m.t24.com.tr/amp/haber/erdogan-cadi-aviysa-biz-bu-cadi-avini-yapacagiz-bunu-da-bilin,258112|title=Erdoğan: Cadı avıysa, biz bu cadı avını yapacağız, bunu da bilin! – Gündem – T24|website=m.t24.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Two months after this announcement, the government arrested and detained police officials who conducted the corruption investigation. The prosecutors of the corruption investigation were also dismissed from their positions.{{cite web|url=http://m.haberturk.com/gundem/haber-amp/1273102-17-25-aralikin-fetocu-polislerine-operasyon|title=17–25 Aralık'ın FETÖ'cü polislerine operasyon – Gündem Haberleri|website=m.haberturk.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://m.mynet.com/1725-aralik-savcilarina-ihrac-guncel-1835160|title=1725 Aralık savcılarına ihraç|first=|last=Aljazeera|website=mynet.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} While Erdoğan has alleged that Zarrab conducted trade and business in aligned with Turkish interests, there have been several reports that suggest Zarrab’s illegal activities extensively harmed the Turkish economy.https://washingtonhatti.com/2017/09/13/zarrab-caglayan-gercekten-ulke-cikarina-mi-calisti-ust-d +uzey-yo neticid en-perde-arkasi/ ==Arrest in the United States== On 19 March 2016, Zarrab was arrested in [[Miami]], Florida, for conspiring to evade [[U.S. sanctions against Iran]] (by using his gold business to help Iran’s government evade the sanctions), [[money laundering]] and [[bank fraud]]. He was later indicted by a grand jury with charges that could bring up to 75 years in prison.{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/turkish-national-arrested-conspiring-evade-us-sanctions-against-iran-money-laundering-and|title=Turkish National Arrested for Conspiring to Evade U.S. Sanctions Against Iran, Money Laundering and Bank Fraud – OPA – Department of Justice|date=3 April 2016|website=archive.org|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403002020/https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/turkish-national-arrested-conspiring-evade-us-sanctions-against-iran-money-laundering-and|archivedate=3 April 2016|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-iran-zarrab/u-s-arrests-turkish-businessman-for-scheme-to-evade-iran-sanctions-idUSKCN0WN295|title=U.S. arrests Turkish businessman accused of evading Iran sanctions|date=21 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 November 2017|via=Reuters}} The case is being prosecuted by the U.S. Attorney for the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|Southern District of New York]], led by [[Preet Bharara]], with assistance from a trial attorney of the National Security Division’s Counterintelligence and Export Control Section. During the case, prosecutors have noted that Zarrab donated $4.5 million to a charity founded by [[Emine Erdoğan]], the wife of former prime minister and now president of Turkey [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]]. Prosecutors stated that Zarrab has "close ties" to Erdoğan.{{cite news|title=US prosecutors say businessman with 'close ties' to Turkey's Erdogan poses flight risk|url=http://www.dw.com/en/us-prosecutors-say-businessman-with-close-ties-to-turkeys-erdogan-poses-flight-risk/a-19283437|work=Deutsche Welle|date=26 May 2016|accessdate=2016-11-06}} After Zarrab's arrest, shares in [[Halk Bankası|Halkbank]], whose CEO was among those charged with taking bribes from Zarrab, had fallen by 20%. He has offered to pay $50 million to be granted a [[bail]]. Bail has been denied. In their brief against granting bail, prosecutors had argued that "if the defendant were able to reach Turkish soil, he could cause the highest levels of Turkish government to block his return to the United States." In April 2017, media reported that negotiations involving the U.S. and Turkish governments were undergoing, to the effect that Zarrab would be extradited to Turkey while in return "Turkey would be much less resistant to the US’s missions in Syria, and primarily its support to the [[Democratic Union Party (Syria)|PYD]]."{{cite news|title=Rudy Giuliani, the jailed Turkish gold trader and the secret meeting with Erdogan |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/us/rudy-giuliani-the-jailed-turkish-gold-trader-and-the-secret-meeting-with-erdogan-1.3056527|publisher=The Irish Times|date=21 April 2017}} One of the most striking arguments in the indictment about Zarrab was that the Zarrab family sent a letter addressed to the president of Iran’s Central Bank and stated that he was ready for "Economic Jihad" against sanctions on Iran.{{cite web|url=https://www.occrp.org/en/azerbaijanilaundromat/notorious-laundromats-used-in-irans-anti-sanction-economic-jihad|title=Notorious Laundromats Used in Iran’s Anti-Sanction ‘Economic Jihad’ – OCCRP|first=Paul Radu and Khadija|last=Ismayilova|website=occrp.org|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Erdoğan's first comment on Zarrab’s arrest by the United States government was: “it was not a case that interests Turkey".{{cite web|url=http://www.ntv.com.tr/amp/turkiye/cumhurbaskani-erdogandan-riza-sarraf-aciklamasi,FGvKyWPapEWAqp0sNaMv4g|title=Cumhurbaşkanı Erdoğan'dan Rıza Sarraf açıklaması – NTV|website=www.ntv.com.tr|accessdate=3 November 2017}} However, it is claimed that Erdoğan, on September 21, 2016 during a special meeting with then Vice President [[Joe Biden]], requested Zarrab's release from jail and prosecutor Bharara to be dismissed from his position. Also, it is claimed that Erdogan’s wife, [[Emine Erdoğan|Emine Erdogan]], did a similar request to Biden’s wife, [[Jill Biden]]. Furthermore, [[Bekir Bozdağ|Bekir Bozdag]], the Turkish Minister of Justice, visited the [[United States Attorney General]] [[Loretta Lynch|Loretta E. Lynch]] in October 2016 and stated how the Zarrab case was unfounded and that Zarrab should be released{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/videos/tv/2017/10/16/tl-preet-bharara-trukey-trump-jake-tapper.cnn|title=Bharara on whether Turkey pushed for his ouster – CNN Video|website=cnn.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}https://www.washingtonpost.com/amphtml/opinions/global-opinions/the-man-at-the-crux-the-of-us-turkey-dispute-is-about-to-go-on-trial/2017/10/12/92c4c7a2-af96-11e7-be94-fabb0f1e9ffb_story.htm By the time, it came out that Zarrab's attorneys, [[Rudy Giuliani|Rudolph W. Giuliani,]] a former New York City mayor, and [[Michael Mukasey|Michael B. Mukasey]], who served as attorney general in President George W. Bush’s administration, held a secret meeting with Erdoğan.{{cite web|url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/04/20/nyregion/rudy-giuliani-reza-zarrab-iran-sanctions-case.html?referer=https://www.google.com.ua/|title=Why Giuliani Held a Secret Meeting With Turkey’s Leader|website=mobile.nytimes.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Halkbank Deputy Chief Executive Mehmet Hakan Atilla, who was in connection with Zarrab, was arrested in the United States in March 2017 with the charges of "conspiring to evade US sanctions against Iran and other offenses”.{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/turkish-banker-arrested-conspiring-evade-us-sanctions-against-iran-and-other-offenses|title=Turkish Banker Arrested For Conspiring To Evade U.S. Sanctions Against Iran And Other Offenses|website=www.justice.gov|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Afterwards, it was announced in September 2017 that the US charged then Turkish Minister of Economic Affairs [[Zafer Çağlayan|Zafer Caglayan]] and former General Manager of Halk Bank Suleyman Aslan with offenses similar to Zarrab's.{{cite web|url=https://washingtonhatti.com/2017/03/29/m-hakan-atilla-iddianamesinde-halkbanka-cok-agir-suclamalar-cikti/|title=M.Hakan Atilla Yakalama Kararında Halkbank'a Çok Ağır Suçlamalar Çıktı -|website=washingtonhatti.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/former-turkish-minister-economy-former-general-manager-turkish-government-owned-bank|title=Former Turkish Minister Of The Economy, Former General Manager Of Turkish Government-Owned Bank, And Two Other Individuals Charged With Conspiring To Evade U.S. Sanctions Against Iran And Other Offenses|website=www.justice.gov|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Erdoğan appeared to be involved in the allegations about the US investigation. It was claimed that Erdogan's effort to save Zarrab was the fear that the inquiry had reached him.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/14/world/europe/turkey-new-york-case.html|title=Why a New York Court Case Has Rattled Turkey’s President|first1=Patrick|last1=Kingsley|first2=Benjamin|last2=Weiser|date=14 October 2017|publisher=|accessdate=3 November 2017|via=www.nytimes.com}} It is also alleged that Erdoğan wanted the US to release Zarrab in return for the detained US citizen pastor Andrew Brunson being held in a prison in Turkey.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/democracy-post/wp/2017/07/07/why-trump-should-not-swap-prisoners-with-erdogan/|title=Opinion – Why Trump should not swap prisoners with Erdogan|website=Washington Post|accessdate=3 November 2017}} Metin Topuz, a Turkish employee of the US Consulate General in Istanbul, was arrested on October 4, 2017 for espionage, being a member of crime network, and taking the evidences of the 2013 corruption investigation to the US. In the arrest warrant, it is emphasized that the main suspects of the December 17th corruption investigation were “foreign intelligence agencies and countries{{cite web|url=http://gazete.netgazete.com/gazeteler.php?id=20|title=Takvim Gazetesi|website=gazete.netgazete.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}” As a response to the arrest, the US Embassy in Turkey announced on October 8, 2017, that "visa applications from Turkey were suspended."{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberght.com/haberler/haber/2055744-abd-vizeleri-askiya-aldi|title=ABD Türkiye'den vize başvurularını askıya aldı – Bloomberg HT|website=bloomberght.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} On November 16, 2017, ''NBC News,'' reported that Zarrab is now cooperating with federal prosecutors in a [[Money laundering|money-laundering]] case and that he was then out of jail, a move President Erdoğan had been desperately hoping to avoid{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/does-cooperating-witness-have-info-flynn-tie-turkey-n821341|title=Does cooperating witness have info on Flynn tie to Turkey?|work=NBC News|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en}}. It is thought that Zarrab is [[Robert Mueller]]'s key to taking down Michael T. Flynn in the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|2017 Special Counsel Investigation]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/did-the-feds-flip-turkish-businessman-reza-zarraband-could-he-bring-down-michael-flynn|title=Did the Feds Flip Turkish Businessman Reza Zarrab—and Could He Bring Down Michael Flynn?|last=Zavadski|first=Katie|date=2017-11-16|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2017-11-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/turkish-iranian-businessman-zarrab-gold-trade-erdogan-ties-iran-sanctions-case-reported-cooperating-us-prosecutors/28859053.html|title=Man Accused In U.S. Iran Sanctions Case Reported Working With Prosecutors|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|access-date=2017-11-17}} In response to Zarrab's release from detention to another facility inside the United States, the Turkish government expressed concern as to the status of Zarrab.{{Cite news|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/11/turkey-demands-info-reza-zarrab.html|title=Turkey demands news as Zarrab drops off radar|last=kjenson|date=2017-11-16|work=Al-Monitor|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-us|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6vOW5patk?url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/11/turkey-demands-info-reza-zarrab.html|archivedate=2017-12-01|df=}} Two weeks later, Zarrab reappeared in Manhattan court as a witness in the case against Atilla, having accepted a plea deal with federal prosecutors.{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/gold-trader-zarrab-will-be-star-witness-iran-sanction-busting-n824351|title=Gold trader Zarrab will be star witness in Iran sanction-busting trial|publisher=NBC News|date=28 November 2017}} A day after Zarrab testified in US Federal District Court, the Turkish government seized the assets of his and his family, including his wife Ebru Gündeş.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/01/world/europe/erdogan-turkey-iran-sanctions.html |title=Turkey Seizes Assets of Reza Zarrab, Witness in Sanctions-Evasion Case |author=Benjamin Weiser |date=1 December 2017 |website=[[NYTimes.com]] |access-date=4 December 2017}} ==Personal life== Zarrab is married to the Turkish singer [[Ebru Gündeş]]. They have one child together. Ebru Gündeş reportedly filed for divorce in September 2016,{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/son-dakika-haberi-ebru-gundes-ile-reza-zarrab-bosaniyor-40230898|title=Ebru Gündeş'ten 'boşanma' için ilk açıklama|language=Turkish|publisher=Hürriyet|date=25 September 2016|accessdate=8 September 2017}} but the couple reconciled shortly afterwards.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/bosanma-davasinda-surpriz-gelisme-40314705|title=Reza Zarrab ile Ebru Gündeş'in boşanma davasında sürpriz gelişme|language=Turkish|publisher=Hürriyet|date=4 August 2017|accessdate=8 September 2017}} ==Export award== In June 2015, Zarrab received the Turkish Export Award jointly from the hands of [[Prime Minister of Turkey|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Numan Kurtulmuş]], [[Ministry of Economy (Turkey)|Minister of Economy]] [[Nihat Zeybekçi]], and President of the Turkish Exporters Council Mehmet Büyükekşi, in a ceremony attended by President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mashreghnews.ir/fa/news/432684/%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AA-%D8%AA%D8%B1%DA%A9%DB%8C%D9%87-%D8%A8%D9%87-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%B6%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A8-%D8%AC%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B2%D9%87-%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D8%B9%DA%A9%D8%B3 |title=دولت ترکیه به رضا ضراب جایزه داد +عکس|publisher=[[Mashregh]] |date= |accessdate=2015-06-23}}{{cite news |title=Reza Zarrab'a ihracat ödülü |trans-title=Export award for Reza Zarrab |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/reza-zarraba-ihracat-odulu-29344202 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |date=22 June 2015 |accessdate=23 March 2016}} ==See also== * [[Babak Zanjani]], Iranian businessman ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zarrab, Reza}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Gold investments]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Iranian Azerbaijani businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Tabriz]] [[Category:Naturalized citizens of Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish people of Iranian descent]] [[Category:Turkish people of Azerbaijani descent]]

revision.comment: Changes WAS to IS, as he is still alive
revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} [[File:Ricardo Belmont 3.jpg|thumb|Ricardo Belmont Cassinelli]] '''Ricardo Belmont Cassinelli''' is a [[Peru]]vian [[TV network]] owner and politician. He was the mayor of [[Lima]]<ref name="FoxFox1997">{{cite book|last1=Fox|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Fox|first2=Fox de Cardona|title=Latin American broadcasting: from tango to telenovela|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9g63lxssFP8C&pg=PA87|accessdate=7 April 2011|year=1997|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-1-86020-515-6|page=87}}</ref> from 1990 to 1995. He was popularly known as "El Hermanón" (Big Brother) for his friendliness and also as "El Colora'o" (Ginger) because of his reddish hair.
==Career== Ricardo Belmont is the son of Augusto Belmont Bar, who founded TV Bego Excelsior (Channel 11 in Peru) in 1967. TV Bego Excelsior also owned Excelsior FM radio (104.7 FM in Peru). The younger Belmont was an avid sportsman who enjoyed [[soccer]] and [[boxing]], and was a patron of players in both sports. His sports passion would later influence him in his political speeches, using sporting terms such as "let's all kick into the same goal post", and, during his reelection bid, "Second half time is about to start, and it's works vs. words. Choose the tree [his electoral [[symbol]]] and we'll win the game." In his "serious" life, he dedicated himself to [[journalism]], befriending several local and national politicians all the while aspiring to be his own man in the media business. In his spare time he also dedicated his life to worthy causes, the most prominent being the local '''Telethon''' (based on the American version by [[Jerry Lewis]]), dedicated to helping the disabled kids at the San Juan de Dios Clinic in Lima.
In 1986 he took over Channel 11 and renamed it Red Bicolor de Comunicaciones (''Bicolor Communications Network''; the initials RBC allude to his personal name). Initially airing only from noon to midnight, Belmont mostly purchased American programming such as [[Bonanza]], [[Get Smart]], [[Bravestarr]], and [[The Twilight Zone]] (the 1985 version). The few RBC-produced shows included "Desafio Familiar", which was a Peruvian version of [[Family Feud]], "Habla el Pueblo", a [[Larry King]]-inspired talk show with Belmont himself as host, and "Mirando la Música", a [[music video]] program. In the late 1980s RBC started diversifying to break out of the niche market to compete with the Peruvian Big Two, America Television and Panamericana Television. RBC Radio 980 AM was mostly sports talk, while 91.9 FM was adult contemporary, in addition to Excelsior, which was mostly tropical and salsa.
In 1990 he announced his candidacy for the Lima provincial mayoralty as an independent. His political party, OBRAS (Works) alluded to the need for public works in Lima and the overall lack of progress as mayor by [[Jorge del Castillo Gálvez]], who was seen more as a lackey of Peruvian President [[Alan García]] than as an effective mayor. Although he supported [[Mario Vargas Llosa]]'s Presidential candidacy, he chose to oppose Vargas Llosa's party's chosen mayoral candidate, [[Juan Inchaustegui]]. Belmont's charisma developed as a TV host and his lack of political affiliation helped him earn the people's vote, and he began to start his public-works program, which included several road and community improvement projects detailed below.
Initially Belmont and the new Peruvian president, [[Alberto Fujimori]], were seen as comrades in arms because of their common political backgrounds as independents. The fiercely independent Belmont, however, drawing on his business skills, was able to get funds from several private enterprises to fund his programs.
Among the many public works projects he completed include: *Intercambio Vial Norte (Northern Interchange): was a paving of Avenida Universitaria linking Carabayllo and San Miguel districts, with an interchange with Panamericana Norte along the way. *Intercambio Vial Este (Eastern Interchange): was a combination of two new bridges spanning the Rimac River linking El Agustino directly with San Juan de Lurigancho *Intercambio Vial Sur (Southern Interchange): was an actual [[Interchange (road)|interchange]] between Panamericana Sur, Av. Circunvalacion and Av. Javier Prado that eliminated traffic light crossings. *Several ''losa deportiva''s (sports grounds) for poor communities, mostly [[concrete]] fields for mini-soccer, basketball, and squash.
Elected to a second term in 1994, Belmont and Fujimori had a falling out, due to resentment from Fujimori at Belmont's former support of Vargas Llosa. Fujimori, through his party-controlled Congress, issued Legislative Decree No. 776, by which provincial mayors were forced to distribute their government income down to the distrital halls under them (particularly from rich to poor distrital municipalities in the interior of the country). This stopped Belmont from pursuing further public works and improvements, and the municipal employees (most of whom were APRA party members left over from the Castillo administration) began turning against him through demonstrations, increasing his unpopularity.
==See also== * [[Lima]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.ricardobelmontcassinelli.com/}}
{{commons category|Ricardo Belmont}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Jorge del Castillo Gálvez]] | title = [[List of mayors of Lima|Mayor of Lima]]| years = 1990–1995| after = ''[[Alberto Andrade Carmona]]''}} {{s-end}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cassinelli, Ricardo Belmont}} [[Category:People from Lima]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Mayors of Lima]] [[Category:Peruvian people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Peruvian people of French descent]] [[Category:Peruvian media executives]] [[Category:Peruvian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{copy edit|date=October 2018}}{{refimprove|date=October 2018}}{{Too few opinions|date=October 2018}}}} [[File:Smallwhatisclingov.jpg|thumb|Governance Technique]] '''Service governance''' is a means of achieving good [[corporate governance]] through governing internal corporate [[Service (business)|services]] across, and throughout, an enterprise{{fact|date=October 2018}}. Even though the initial focus was on IT services,<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://doi.org/10.1007/s10799-015-0239-z|title=Defining the relationships between IT service management and IT service governance|first1=Marko|last1=Jäntti|first2=Virpi|last2=Hotti|date=30 June 2015|journal=Information Technology and Management|volume=17|issue=2|pages=141–150|accessdate=17 October 2018|doi=10.1007/s10799-015-0239-z}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=October 2018}} it can include accounting, business administration, and other internal service sectors. Institutionalizing these services enables the monitoring and control of risk, value, and cost.<ref>{{cite book|last1=AXELOS|title=Adopting Service Governance: Governing Portfolio Value for Sound Corporate Citizenship|publisher=The Stationery Office|isbn=9780113314652|page=6|date=2015-08-11}}</ref> Principle among the issues is the fair funding for each service and the allocation system for scarce services.
Institutionalizing internal corporate services is the corporate management equivalent a [[General Ledger|general ledger]], only with the line items reflecting the services, not simply departments. The service portfolio allows the governance of services as a means to govern the organization by [[Value (ethics)|value]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Betz |first1=Charles T. |title=Architecture and patterns for IT service management, resource planning, and governance : making shoes for the cobbler's children |date=2007 |publisher=Elsevier/Morgan Kaufmann |isbn=9780123705938}}</ref>
==Service portfolio== The portfolio of services is a list of all internal services within the organization that is available outside their own department. The portfolio describes each service, how it is funded, associated costs, ownership boundaries, along with its current performance and identified conflicts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://service-governance.org/index.php?title=Best_Practice/Service_Portfolio |title=Service Portfolio |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222074953/http://service-governance.org/index.php?title=Best_Practice/Service_Portfolio |archivedate=December 22, 2015 }}</ref>{{better source|date=October 2018}} This portfolio contains all services in the organization, including those which have been [[Outsourcing|outsourced]] and are now supplied to the organization by third parties.
The portfolio provides a map of the organization that provides directors with a different way of understanding the dynamics of the organization than that received from financial reports, and, thus, makes it easier for the board to make decisions based on accurate, contemporaneous information.
==Value== Service governance uses the methods described in the management of value (MoV) to discover the requirements of the organization and to use those on design services, and their measures to deliver those values.<ref>Vásquez, W. (2013). An economic valuation of water connections under different approaches of service governance. Water Resources and Economics, 2-3, 17-29.</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Handbook of research on service-oriented systems and non-functional properties : future directions |publisher=IGI Global (701 E. Chocolate Avenue, Hershey, Pennsylvania, 17033, USA) |isbn=978-1-61350-432-1}}</ref>
==Measurement and compliance== Well established best practice methods are used to design measures and metrics for the organization. These are designed to meet the requirements of the corporate mission, charter, and policy. This ensures that they measure what is required by the organization and, thus, supply accurate real-time information to the board for strategic governance decisions, and to management for operational decisions.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cai |first1=Hongming |last2=Xu |first2=Lida |last3=Xu |first3=Boyi |last4=Zhang |first4=Pengzhu |last5=Guo |first5=Jingzhi |last6=Zhang |first6=Yuran |title=A service governance mechanism based on process mining for cloud-based applications |journal=Enterprise Information Systems |date=22 February 2018 |pages=1–18 |doi=10.1080/17517575.2018.1442933}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gómez-Baggethun |first1=Erik |last2=Kelemen |first2=Eszter |last3=Martín-López |first3=Berta |last4=Palomo |first4=Ignacio |last5=Montes |first5=Carlos |title=Scale Misfit in Ecosystem Service Governance as a Source of Environmental Conflict |journal=Society & Natural Resources |date=October 2013 |volume=26 |issue=10 |pages=1202–1216 |doi=10.1080/08941920.2013.820817}}</ref>
This also ensures compliance with the requirements of Audit as well as enabling the production of the financial and sustainability report and reporting on good corporate citizenship.
== Enterprise service management == Enterprise service management (ESM) is a means of extending service management across an entire organization, often from IT service management ([[ITSM]]). It is a component of service governance.<ref>[http://service-governance.org/index.php?title=Enterprise_Service_Management] {{dead link|date=October 2018}}</ref>
ESM provides an integrated view of core service business processes, often in real-time, using common databases. ESM systems track business resources—people, parts, assets—and the status of customer commitments: service requests, orders, repairs, and SLAs. The applications that make up the system share data across various departments (customer service, technical support, sales, field service, etc.) that use the information for their work. ESM facilitates information flow between departments and coordinates activities with external resources involved in the service business process.
Enterprise service management is also a term used to sometimes generically describe the use of [[Service (business)|service]] processes and technologies across an organization. It is meant to be a broader term (like ERP and EAM) in contrast to [[IT Service Management|IT service management]] which only concerns the management of IT services.
==History== The term has been used to describe the success that a number of organizations have had in using the ''Best Practice'' advice, found in frameworks such as [[ITIL]], [[The_Open_Group_Architecture_Framework|TOGAF]], and others, for company-wide service design and operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240184788/Cern-uses-ITIL-to-rethink-facilities-management|title=CERN uses ITIL to rethink facilities management|website=Computerweekly.com|accessdate=17 October 2018}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=October 2018}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ifc.org/corporategovernance WorldBank/IFC Corporate Governance Portal] * [http://www.worldbank.org/ifa/rosc_cg.html World Bank Corporate Governance Reports]
{{corporate titles}}
